paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
My lord, what's wrong with you? You're not doing yourself any good by refusing to tell your friends what's bothering you.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Sir, I lack advancement.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Sir, I have no future ahead of me.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
How can that be, when you have the voice of the king himself for your succession in Denmark?
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
But how can you say that, when the king himself says you're the heir to the Danish throne?

paragraphs.original:
Reenter the PLAYERS with recorders
PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated:
The PLAYERS enter with
recorders .
PLAYERS
recorders

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Ay, sir, but "While the grass grows - " The proverb is something musty - Oh, the recorders! Let me see one. (takes a recorder) (aside to ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN ) To withdraw with you, why do you go about to recover the wind of me as if you would drive me into a toil?
(takes a recorder)
(aside to
and
)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Yes, eventually, but as the proverb goes,
"While the grass grows …" But that's a tired old proverb. Oh, the recorders! Let me see one.(he takes a recorder and turns to GUILDENSTERN ) Why are you hovering so close, as if you want to ambush me?
"While the grass grows …"



(he takes a recorder and turns to
)

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
O my lord, if my duty be too bold, my love is too unmannerly.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
Oh, my lord, I'm sorry if I'm forgetting my manners. It's just that I'm worried about you.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I do not well understand that. Will you play upon this pipe?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I don't really understand what you mean. Will you play this recorder?

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
My lord, I cannot.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
I can't, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I pray you.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Please.

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
Believe me, I cannot.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
I'm serious, I can't.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I do beseech you.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'm begging you.

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
I know no touch of it, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
I have no idea how.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
It is as easy as lying. Govern these ventages with your fingers and thumb, give it breath with your mouth, and it will discourse most eloquent music. Look you, these are the stops.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Oh, it's as easy as lying. Just put your fingers and thumb over the holes and blow into it, and it'll produce the most moving music. Here, the holes are here.

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
But these cannot I command to any utterance of harmony.
I have not the skill.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
But I can't play a melody. I don't know how.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, look you now, how unworthy a thing you make of me! You would play upon me. You would seem to know my stops. You would pluck out the heart of my mystery. You would sound me from my lowest note to the top of my compass. And there is much music, excellent voice, in this little organ, yet cannot you make it speak? 'Sblood, do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe? Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, yet you cannot play upon me.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Well, look how you play me - as if you knew exactly where to put your fingers, to blow the mystery out of me, playing all the octaves of my range - and yet you can't even produce music from this little instrument? My God, do you think I'm easier to manipulate than a pipe? You can push my buttons, but you can't play me for a fool.

paragraphs.original:
Enter POLONIUS
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS enters.
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original: God bless you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Hello and God bless you, sir.

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
My lord, the queen wants to speak with you right away.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a camel?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Do you see that cloud up there that looks like a camel?

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
By th' mass, and 'tis like a camel indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
By God, it does look like a camel.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Methinks it is like a weasel.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
To me it looks like a weasel.

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
It is backed like a weasel.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
It does have a back like a weasel's.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Or like a whale.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Or like a whale.

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
Very like a whale.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
Yes, very much like a whale.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Then I will come to my mother by and by. (aside) They fool me to the top of my bent. - I will come by and by.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'll go see my mother soon. (to himself) They're trying as hard as they can to mess with me. - I will go soon.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
I will say so.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
I'll tell her.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
"By and by" is easily said.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
It's easy enough to say "soon."

paragraphs.original:
Exit POLONIUS
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS exits.
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original: Leave me, friends.
paragraphs.translated: Now please leave me alone, my friends.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt all but HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
'Tis now the very witching time of night,
When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out
Contagion to this world. Now could I drink hot blood
And do such bitter business as the bitter day
Would quake to look on. Soft, now to my mother. - 
O heart, lose not thy nature, let not ever
The soul of Nero enter this firm bosom.
Let me be cruel, not unnatural.
paragraphs.translated:
This is the time of night when witches come out, when graveyards yawn open and the stench of hell seeps out. I could drink hot blood and do such terrible deeds that people would tremble even in the daylight. But I've got to go see my mother. - Oh, heart, don't grow weak, like
Nero Let me be cruel, but not inhuman.
Nero

paragraphs.original:
I will speak daggers to her but use none.
My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites.
How in my words somever she be shent,
To give them seals never, my soul, consent!
paragraphs.translated: I'll speak as sharp as a dagger to her, but I won't use one on her. And so, my words and thoughts will be at odds.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
Enter CLAUDIUS, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN
CLAUDIUS
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN enter.
CLAUDIUS
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
I like him not, nor stands it safe with us
To let his madness range. Therefore prepare you.
I your commission will forthwith dispatch,
And he to England shall along with you.
The terms of our estate may not endure
Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow
Out of his lunacies.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
I don't like the way he's acting, and it's not safe for me to let his insanity get out of control. So get prepared. I'm sending you to England on diplomatic business, and Hamlet will go with you. As king, I cannot risk the danger he represents as he grows crazier by the hour.

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
We will ourselves provide.
Most holy and religious fear it is
To keep those many, many bodies safe
That live and feed upon your majesty.
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
We'll take care of it. It's a sacred duty to protect the lives of all those who depend on Your Highness.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
The single and peculiar life is bound
With all the strength and armor of the mind
To keep itself from noyance, but much more
That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest
The lives of many. The cease of majesty
Dies not alone, but, like a gulf, doth draw
What's near it with it. It is a massy wheel
Fixed on the summit of the highest mount,
To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things
Are mortised and adjoined, which, when it falls,
Each small annexment, petty consequence,
Attends the boisterous ruin. Never alone
Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
Everyone tries to avoid harm, but the public figure demands even more protection. When a great leader dies he doesn't die alone but, like a whirlpool, draws others with him. He's like a huge wheel on the top of the highest mountain whose spokes touch the rim of ten thousand smaller things - when it falls down the mountain, every little object goes down with it. Whenever a king sighs, everyone groans.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Arm you, I pray you, to this speedy voyage.
For we will fetters put upon this fear,
Which now goes too free-footed.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Prepare yourself, please, for this trip. We'll put a leash on this danger that's now running wild.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We will haste us.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We'll hurry.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
Enter POLONIUS
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS enters.
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
My lord, he's going to his mother's closet.
Behind the arras I'll convey myself
To hear the process. I'll warrant she'll tax him home.
And, as you said (and wisely was it said)
'Tis meet that some more audience than a mother - 
Since nature makes them partial - should o'erhear
The speech, of vantage. Fare you well, my liege.
I'll call upon you ere you go to bed
And tell you what I know.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
My lord, Hamlet's going to his mother's room. I'll hide behind the tapestry to hear what they say. I bet she'll chew him out. And as you said (and you said it wisely), it's good to have someone other than a mother listening in on them, since she can be too partial to him. Goodbye, my lord. I'll stop by before you go to bed, and tell you what I've heard.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Thanks, dear my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Thanks, my dear lord.

paragraphs.original:
Exit POLONIUS
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS exits.
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
Oh, my offence is rank. It smells to heaven.
It hath the primal eldest curse upon 't,
A brother's murder. Pray can I not.
Though inclination be as sharp as will,
My stronger guilt defeats my strong intent,
And, like a man to double business bound,
I stand in pause where I shall first begin,
And both neglect. What if this cursèd hand
Were thicker than itself with brother's blood?
Is there not rain enough in the sweet heavens
To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy
But to confront the visage of offence?
And what's in prayer but this twofold force,
To be forestallèd ere we come to fall
Or pardoned being down? Then I'll look up.
My fault is past. But oh, what form of prayer
Can serve my turn, "Forgive me my foul murder"?
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, my crime is so rotten it stinks all the way to heaven. It has the mark of
Cain on it, a brother's murder. I can't pray, though I want to desperately. My guilt is stronger even than my intentions. And like a person with two opposite things to do at once, I stand paralyzed and neglect them both. So what if this cursed hand of mine is coated with my brother's blood? Isn't there enough rain in heaven to wash it clean as snow? Isn't that what God's mercy is for? And doesn't prayer serve these two purposes - to keep us from sinning and to bring us forgiveness when we have sinned? So I'll pray. I've already committed my sin. But, oh, what kind of prayer is there for me? "Dear Lord, forgive me for my horrible murder"?
Cain

paragraphs.original:
That cannot be, since I am still possessed
Of those effects for which I did the murder:
My crown, mine own ambition, and my queen.
May one be pardoned and retain th' offense?
In the corrupted currents of this world
Offense's gilded hand may shove by justice,
And oft 'tis seen the wicked prize itself
Buys out the law. But 'tis not so above.
There is no shuffling. There the action lies
In his true nature, and we ourselves compelled,
Even to the teeth and forehead of our faults,
To give in evidence. What then? What rests?
Try what repentance can. What can it not?
Yet what can it when one can not repent?
O wretched state! O bosom black as death!
O limèd soul that, struggling to be free,
Art more engaged! Help, angels. Make assay.
Bow, stubborn knees, and, heart with strings of steel,
Be soft as sinews of the newborn babe.
All may be well. (kneels)
(kneels)
paragraphs.translated:
That won't work, since I'm still reaping the rewards of that murder: my crown and my queen. Can a person be forgiven and still keep the fruits of his crime? In this wicked world, criminals often take the money they stole and use it to buy off the law, shoving justice aside. But not in heaven. Up there, every action is judged for exactly what it's worth, and we're forced to confront our crimes. So what can I do? What is there left to do? Offer whatever repentance I can - that couldn't hurt. But it can't help either! Oh, what a lousy situation I'm in. My heart's as black as death. My soul is stuck to sin, and the more it struggles to break free, the more it sticks. Help me, angels! C'mon, make an effort. Bend, stubborn knees. Steely heart, be soft as a newborn babe, so I can pray. Perhaps everything will turn out okay after all. (he kneels)
he kneels)

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET enters.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Now might I do it pat. Now he is a-praying.
And now I'll do 't. And so he goes to heaven.
And so am I revenged. - That would be scanned.
A villain kills my father, and, for that,
I, his sole son, do this same villain send
To heaven.
Oh, this is hire and salary, not revenge.
He took my father grossly, full of bread,
With all his crimes broad blown, as flush as May.
And how his audit stands who knows save heaven?
But in our circumstance and course of thought
'Tis heavy with him. And am I then revenged
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I could do it easily now. He's praying now. And now I'll do it. (he draws out his sword) And there he goes, off to heaven. And that's my revenge. I'd better think about this more carefully. A villain kills my father, and I, my father's only son, send this same villain to heaven. Seems like I just did him a favor. He killed my father when my father was enjoying life, with all his sins in full bloom, before my father could repent for any of them. Only God knows how many sins my father has to pay for. As for me, I don't think his prospects look so good.
(he draws out his sword)

paragraphs.original:
To take him in the purging of his soul
When he is fit and seasoned for his passage?
No.
Up, sword, and know thou a more horrid hent.
When he is drunk asleep, or in his rage,
Or in th' incestuous pleasure of his bed,
At game a-swearing, or about some act
That has no relish of salvation in 't - 
Then trip him, that his heels may kick at heaven,
And that his soul may be as damned and black
As hell, whereto it goes. My mother stays
This physic but prolongs thy sickly days.
paragraphs.translated:
So is it really revenge for me if I kill Claudius right when he is confessing his sins, in perfect condition for a trip to heaven? No. Away, sword, and wait for a better moment to kill him. (he puts his sword away) When he's sleeping off some drunken orgy, or having incestuous sex, or swearing while he gambles, or committing some other act that has no goodness about it - that's when I'll trip him up and send him to hell with his heels kicking up at heaven. My mother's waiting. The king's trying to cure himself with prayer, but all he's doing is keeping himself alive a little longer.
(he puts his sword away)

paragraphs.original:
Exit HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
(rises) My words fly up, my thoughts remain below.
(rises)
Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
(rising) My words fly up toward heaven, but my thoughts stay down here on earth. Words without thoughts behind them will never make it to heaven.
(rising)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS exits.
CLAUDIUS

paragraphs.original:
Enter GERTRUDE and POLONIUS
GERTRUDE
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDEand POLONIUS enter.
GERTRUDE
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
He will come straight. Look you lay home to him.
Tell him his pranks have been too broad to bear with,
And that your grace hath screened and stood between
Much heat and him. I'll silence me even here.
Pray you, be round with him.
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
He'll come right away. Make sure you lay into him. Tell him his pranks have caused too much trouble, and that Your Highness has taken a lot of heat for them. I'll be right here, silent. Please be blunt with him.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
(within) Mother, mother, mother!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(offstage) Mother, mother, mother!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
I'll warrant you. Fear me not. Withdraw, I hear him coming.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Don't worry, I'll do what you say. Now hide, I hear him coming.

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS hides behind the arras
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS hides behind the tapestry.
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET enters.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Now mother, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Now mother, what's this all about?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Hamlet, you've insulted your father.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Mother, you have my father much offended.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Mother, you've insulted my father.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Come on, you're answering me foolishly.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Go, go, you question with a wicked tongue.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Go on, you're questioning me evilly.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Why, how now, Hamlet?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Hamlet, what, why?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
What's the matter now?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What's the problem now?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Have you forgot me?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Have you forgotten who I am?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
No, by the rood, not so.
You are the queen, your husband's brother's wife,
And - would it were not so! - you are my mother.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
For God's sake no, I haven't. You are the queen, your husband's brother's wife, and you are my mother, though I wish you weren't.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Nay, then I'll set those to you that can speak.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
In that case I'll call in others who can still speak.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Come, come, and sit you down. You shall not budge.
You go not till I set you up a glass
Where you may see the inmost part of you.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
No, sit down. You won't budge until I hold a mirror up to you, where you will see what's deep inside you.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
What wilt thou do? Thou wilt not murder me?
Help, help, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
What are you going to do? You won't kill me, will you? Help!

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
(from behind the arras) What, ho? Help, help, help!
(from behind the arras)
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
(from behind the tapestry) Hey! Help, help, help!
(from behind the tapestry)

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How now, a rat? Dead for a ducat, dead!
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What's this, a rat? I'll bet a buck he's a dead rat now.

paragraphs.original:
(stabs his sword through the arras and kills POLONIUS)
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
(he stabs his sword through the tapestry and kills POLONIUS)
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
POLONIUS
(from behind the arras) Oh, I am slain.
(from behind the arras)
paragraphs.translated:
POLONIUS
(from behind the tapestry) Oh, I've been killed!
(from behind the tapestry)

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
O me, what hast thou done?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh my God, what have you done?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Nay, I know not. Is it the king?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I don't know. Is it the king?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Oh, what a rash and bloody deed is this!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh, what a senseless, horrible act!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
A bloody deed? Almost as bad, good mother,
As kill a king and marry with his brother.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A horrible act - almost as bad, my good mother, as killing a king and marrying his brother.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
As kill a king?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Killing a king?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Ay, lady, 'twas my word.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That's what I said, my good woman.

paragraphs.original:
(draws back the arras and discovers POLONIUS)
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
(he pulls back the tapestry and discovers POLONIUS)
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool, farewell.
I took thee for thy better. Take thy fortune.
Thou find'st to be too busy is some danger.
(to GERTRUDE) Leave wringing of your hands. Peace. Sit you down
(to
)
And let me wring your heart. For so I shall
If it be made of penetrable stuff,
If damnèd custom have not brassed it so
That it is proof and bulwark against sense.

GERTRUDE
What have I done, that thou darest wag thy tongue
In noise so rude against me?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
What have I done that you dare to talk to me so rudely?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Such an act
That blurs the grace and blush of modesty,
Calls virtue hypocrite, takes off the rose
From the fair forehead of an innocent love
And sets a blister there, makes marriage vows
As false as dicers' oaths - oh, such a deed
As from the body of contraction plucks
The very soul, and sweet religion makes
A rhapsody of words. Heaven's face doth glow
O'er this solidity and compound mass
With tristful visage, as against the doom,
Is thought-sick at the act.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A deed that destroys modesty, turns virtue into hypocrisy, replaces the blossom on the face of true love with a nasty blemish, makes marriage vows as false as a gambler's oath - oh, you've done a deed that plucks the soul out of marriage and turns religion into meaningless blather. Heaven looks down on this earth, as angry as if Judgment Day were here, and is sick at the thought of what you've done.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Ay me, what act
That roars so loud and thunders in the index?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
C'mon, what's this deed that sounds so awful even before I know what it is?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Look here upon this picture and on this,
The counterfeit presentment of two brothers.
See, what a grace was seated on this brow?
Hyperion's curls, the front of Jove himself,
An eye like Mars to threaten and command,
A station like the herald Mercury
New-lighted on a heaven-kissing hill - 
A combination and a form indeed
Where every god did seem to set his seal
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Look at this picture here, and that one there,
the painted images of two brothers. Look how kind and gentlemanly this one is, with his curly hair and his forehead like a Greek god. His eye could command like the god of war. His body is as agile as Mercury just landing on a high hill.
the painted images of two brothers



A figure and a combination of good qualities that seemed like every god had set his stamp on this man.

paragraphs.original:
To give the world assurance of a man.
This was your husband. Look you now, what follows.
Here is your husband, like a mildewed ear
Blasting his wholesome brother. Have you eyes?
Could you on this fair mountain leave to feed
And batten on this moor? Ha, have you eyes?
You cannot call it love, for at your age
The heyday in the blood is tame, it's humble,
And waits upon the judgment. And what judgment
Would step from this to this? Sense sure you have,
Else could you not have motion. But sure that sense
Is apoplexed, for madness would not err,
Nor sense to ecstasy was ne'er so thralled,
But it reserved some quantity of choice
To serve in such a difference. What devil was 't
That thus hath cozened you at hoodman-blind?
Eyes without feeling, feeling without sight,
Ears without hands or eyes, smelling sans all,
Or but a sickly part of one true sense
Could not so mope. O shame, where is thy blush?
Rebellious hell,
If thou canst mutine in a matron's bones,
To flaming youth let virtue be as wax
And melt in her own fire. Proclaim no shame
When the compulsive ardor gives the charge,
Since frost itself as actively doth burn,
And reason panders will.
paragraphs.translated: That was your husband. Now look at this other one. Here is your present husband, like a mildewed ear of corn infecting the healthy one next to it. Do you have eyes? How could you leave the lofty heights of this man here and descend as low as this one? Ha! Do you have eyes? You cannot say you did it out of love, since at your age romantic passions have grown weak, and the heart obeys reason. But what reason could move you from this one to that one? You must have some sense in your head, since you're able to get around, but it seems to be paralyzed, since even if you were crazy you would know the difference between these two men. No one ever went so insane that they couldn't get an easy choice like this one right. What devil was it that blindfolded you? Eyes without feeling, feeling without sight, ears without hands or eyes, smell without anything else, the use of even one impaired sense would not permit such a mistake as yours. Oh, for shame, why aren't you blushing? If evil can overtake even an old mother's bones, then let it melt my own. It turns out it's no longer shameful to act on impulse - now that the old are doing so, and now that reason is a servant to desire.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
O Hamlet, speak no more!
Thou turn'st mine eyes into my very soul,
And there I see such black and grainèd spots
As will not leave their tinct.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh, Hamlet, stop! You're making me look into my very soul, where the marks of sin are so thick and black they will never be washed away.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Nay, but to live
In the rank sweat of an enseamèd bed,
Stewed in corruption, honeying and making love
Over the nasty sty -
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Yes, and you lie in the sweaty stench of your dirty sheets, wet with corruption, making love -

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
O, speak to me no more!
These words like daggers enter in my ears.
No more, sweet Hamlet.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh, you must stop! Your words are like daggers. Please, no more, sweet Hamlet.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
A murderer and a villain,
A slave that is not twentieth part the tithe
Of your precedent lord, a vice of kings,
A cutpurse of the empire and the rule,
That from a shelf the precious diadem stole,
And put it in his pocket -
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A murderer and a villain, a low-life who's not worth a twentieth of a tenth of your first husband - the worst of kings, a thief of the throne, who took the precious crown from a shelf and put it in his pocket -

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
No more!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Stop!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
A king of shreds and patches -
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A ragtag king -

paragraphs.original:
Enter GHOST
GHOST
paragraphs.translated:
The GHOST enters.
GHOST

paragraphs.original:
Save me and hover o'er me with your wings,
You heavenly guards! - What would your gracious figure?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, angels in heaven, protect me with your wings! - What can I do for you, my gracious lord?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alas, he's mad!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh no! Hamlet's gone completely crazy.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Do you not come your tardy son to chide,
That, lapsed in time and passion, lets go by
The important acting of your dread command?
O, say!
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Have you come to scold your tardy son for straying from his mission, letting your important command slip by? Tell me!

paragraphs.original:
GHOST
Do not forget. This visitation
Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose.
But look, amazement on thy mother sits.
O, step between her and her fighting soul.
Conceit in weakest bodies strongest works.
Speak to her, Hamlet.
paragraphs.translated:
GHOST
Don't forget. I've come to sharpen your somewhat dull appetite for revenge. But look, your mother is in shock. Oh, keep her struggling soul from being overwhelmed by horrid visions. The imagination works strongest in those with the weakest bodies. Talk to her, Hamlet.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How is it with you, lady?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How are you doing, madam?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alas, how is 't with you,
That you do bend your eye on vacancy
And with th' incorporal air do hold discourse?
Forth at your eyes your spirits wildly peep,
And, as the sleeping soldiers in th' alarm,
Your bedded hair, like life in excrements,
Starts up and stands on end. O gentle son,
Upon the heat and flame of thy distemper
Sprinkle cool patience. Whereon do you look?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
And how are you doing, staring into the empty air and talking to nobody? Your eyes give away your wild thoughts, and your hair is standing upright, like soldiers during a call to arms. Oh my dear son, calm yourself and cool off your overheated mind! What are you staring at?
you

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
On him, on him! Look you, how pale he glares!
His form and cause conjoined, preaching to stones,
Would make them capable.
(to GHOST) Do not look upon me,
(to
)
Lest with this piteous action you convert
My stern effects. Then what I have to do
Will want true color - tears perchance for blood.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
At him, at him! Look how pale he is and how he glares at me. Preaching even at stones, he could get them to act. (to the GHOST) Don't look at me like that, unless you want me to cry instead of kill.
(to the
)

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
To whom do you speak this?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Who are you talking to?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Do you see nothing there?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
You don't see anything?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Nothing at all, yet all that is I see.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Nothing at all, but I can see everything that's here.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Nor did you nothing hear?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
And you don't hear anything?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
No, nothing but ourselves.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
No, nothing but us talking.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, look you there! Look how it steals away - 
My father, in his habit as he lived - 
Look where he goes, even now, out at the portal!
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Look, look how it's sneaking away! My father, dressed just like he was when he was alive!
Look, he's going out the door right now!

paragraphs.original:
Exit GHOST
GHOST
paragraphs.translated:
The GHOST exits.
GHOST

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
This the very coinage of your brain.
This bodiless creation ecstasy
Is very cunning in.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
This is only a figment of your imagination. Madness is good at creating hallucinations.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Ecstasy?
My pulse as yours doth temperately keep time
And makes as healthful music. It is not madness
That I have uttered. Bring me to the test,
And I the matter will reword, which madness
Would gambol from. Mother, for love of grace,
Lay not that flattering unction to your soul
That not your trespass but my madness speaks.
It will but skin and film the ulcerous place
Whilst rank corruption, mining all within,
Infects unseen. Confess yourself to heaven.
Repent what's past. Avoid what is to come.
And do not spread the compost on the weeds
To make them ranker. Forgive me this my virtue,
For in the fatness of these pursy times
Virtue itself of vice must pardon beg,
Yea, curb and woo for leave to do him good.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Madness? My heart beats just as evenly as yours does. There's nothing crazy in what I've just uttered. Put me to the test. I'll rephrase everything I've just said, which a lunatic couldn't do. Mother, for the love of God, don't flatter yourself into believing that it's my madness, not your crime, that's the problem. You'd just be concealing the rot that's eating you from the inside. Confess your sins to heaven. Repent and avoid damnation. Don't spread manure over the weeds in your heart; it'll only make them more filthy. Forgive me my good intentions here since in these fat and spoiled times, virtuous people have to say, "Beg your pardon" to vile ones and beg for the chance to do any good.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
O Hamlet, thou hast cleft my heart in twain.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh Hamlet, you've broken my heart in two!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Oh, throw away the worser part of it,
And live the purer with the other half.
Good night - but go not to mine uncle's bed.
Assume a virtue if you have it not.
That monster, custom, who all sense doth eat,
Of habits devil, is angel yet in this:
That to the use of actions fair and good
He likewise gives a frock or livery
That aptly is put on. Refrain tonight,
And that shall lend a kind of easiness
To the next abstinence, the next more easy.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Then throw away the worse half, and live a purer life with the other! Good night to you. But don't go to my uncle's bed tonight. At least pretend to be virtuous, even if you're not. Habit is a terrible thing, in that it's easy to get used to doing evil without feeling bad about it. But it's also a good thing, in that being good can also become a habit.
Say no to sex tonight, and that will make it easier to say no the next time, and still easier the time after that. Habit can change even one's natural instincts, and either rein in the devil in us, or kick him out. Once again, good night to you, and when you want to repent, I'll ask you for your blessing too. I'm sorry about what happened to this gentleman (pointing to POLONIUS), but
(pointing to
)

paragraphs.original:
For use almost can change the stamp of nature,
And either rein the devil or throw him out
With wondrous potency. Once more, good night,
And when you are desirous to be blessed,
I'll blessing beg of you. (points to POLONIUS)
(points to
)
For this same lord,
I do repent. But heaven hath pleased it so,
To punish me with this and this with me,
That I must be their scourge and minister.
I will bestow him and will answer well
The death I gave him. So, again, good night.
I must be cruel only to be kind.
Thus bad begins and worse remains behind.
One word more, good lady -
paragraphs.translated: God wanted to punish me with this murder, and this man with me, so I'm both Heaven's executioner and its minister of justice. This is bad, but it'll get worse soon. Oh, and one other thing, madam.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
What shall I do?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
What should I do?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Not this, by no means, that I bid you do - 
Let the bloat king tempt you again to bed,
Pinch wanton on your cheek, call you his mouse,
And let him, for a pair of reechy kisses
Or paddling in your neck with his damned fingers,
Make you to ravel all this matter out:
That I essentially am not in madness
But mad in craft. 'Twere good you let him know,
For who that's but a queen, fair, sober, wise,
Would from a paddock, from a bat, a gib,
Such dear concernings hide? Who would do so?
No, in despite of sense and secrecy,
Unpeg the basket on the house's top.
Let the birds fly, and like the famous ape,
To try conclusions, in the basket creep
And break your own neck down.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Whatever you do, don't do this: let the fat king seduce you into his bed again, so he can pinch your cheek, call you his bunny, and with filthy kisses and a massage of your neck with his damned fingers, make you admit that my madness is fake, all calculated. What a great idea that would be, because why would a fair, sober, wise queen hide such things from a toad, a pig, a monster like him? Who would do that? No, no, it's much, much better to spill the beans right away, let the cat out of the bag, and break your neck in the process.
much, much

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Be thou assured, if words be made of breath
And breath of life, I have no life to breathe
What thou hast said to me.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
You can rest easy, since words are made of breath, and breathing requires that you be alive. I feel too dead to breathe a word of what you've told me.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I must to England, you know that?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I have to go to England, don't you know that?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alack,
I had forgot. 'Tis so concluded on.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Ah, I'd forgotten all about that! It's been decided.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
There's letters sealed, and my two schoolfellows,
Whom I will trust as I will adders fanged,
They bear the mandate. They must sweep my way
And marshal me to knavery. Let it work,
For 'tis the sport to have the engineer
Hoist with his own petard. And 't shall go hard,
But I will delve one yard below their mines,
And blow them at the moon. Oh, 'tis most sweet
When in one line two crafts directly meet.
(indicates POLONIUS )
(indicates
)
This man shall set me packing.
I'll lug the guts into the neighbor room.
Mother, good night. Indeed this counselor
Is now most still, most secret, and most grave
Who was in life a foolish prating knave. - 
Come, sir, to draw toward an end with you. - 
Good night, mother.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Yes, it's a done deal, the documents are ready, and my two schoolmates, whom I trust about as much as rattlesnakes, are in charge. They're the ones who'll lead me on my march to mischief. Let it happen. It's fun to watch the engineer get blown up by his own explosives, and with any luck I'll dig a few feet below their bombs and blow them to the moon. Oh, it's nice to kill two birds with one stone. (points to POLONIUS) Now that I've killed this guy, I'll be off in a hurry. I'll lug his guts into the next room. Mother, have a good night. This politician who was in life a babbling idiot is now quiet and serious. Come on, sir, let's get to the end of our business. Good night, mother.
points to
)

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt, HAMLET tugging in POLONIUS
HAMLET
POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
They exit, HAMLET dragging POLONIUS offstage.
HAMLET
POLONIUS

paragraphs.original:
Enter King CLAUDIUS and Queen GERTRUDE, with ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
CLAUDIUS
GERTRUDE
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS and GERTRUDE enter with ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN.
CLAUDIUS
GERTRUDE
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
(to GERTRUDE) There's matter in these sighs, these profound heaves.
(to
)
You must translate. 'Tis fit we understand them.
Where is your son?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
(to GERTRUDE) These deep, heaving sighs of yours mean something. You have to tell me what. I need to know. Where's your son?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
(to ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN)
(to
and
)
Bestow this place on us a little while.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
(to ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN) Let us speak privately awhile, please.
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original: Ah, my good lord, what have I seen tonight!
paragraphs.translated: Ah, my lord, you wouldn't believe what I've witnessed tonight!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
What, Gertrude? How does Hamlet?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
What, Gertrude? How is Hamlet?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Mad as the sea and wind when both contend
Which is the mightier. In his lawless fit,
Behind the arras hearing something stir,
Whips out his rapier, cries, "A rat, a rat!"
And in this brainish apprehension kills
The unseen good old man.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
As mad as the waves and the wind when they struggle together in a storm. In an insane rage, he hears something behind the tapestry, whips out his sword, shouts, "A rat, a rat!" and in his deranged state of mind he kills the good old man, who is still hidden.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
O heavy deed!
It had been so with us, had we been there.
His liberty is full of threats to all - 
To you yourself, to us, to everyone.
Alas, how shall this bloody deed be answered?
It will be laid to us, whose providence
Should have kept short, restrained and out of haunt,
This mad young man. But so much was our love,
We would not understand what was most fit,
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Oh, this is terrible! It would've happened to me if I'd been there. His wildness is a threat to all of us - to you, to me, to everyone. How will we deal with this violent deed? I'm the one who will be blamed for not restraining and confining this mad young man. But I loved him so much I didn't want to think about what I had to do.
So, like someone suffering from a nasty disease who refuses to divulge his condition and lets it infect him to

paragraphs.original:
But, like the owner of a foul disease,
To keep it from divulging, let it feed
Even on the pith of life. Where is he gone?
paragraphs.translated: the core, I kept Hamlet's condition secret and let it grow more and more dangerous. Where has he gone?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
To draw apart the body he hath killed,
O'er whom his very madness, like some ore
Among a mineral of metals base,
Shows itself pure. He weeps for what is done.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
To remove the corpse of the man he killed. His madness allows a glimmering of morality to shine through, like a vein of gold in a chunk of coal. He weeps for what he has done.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
O Gertrude, come away!
The sun no sooner shall the mountains touch
But we will ship him hence, and this vile deed
We must, with all our majesty and skill,
Both countenance and excuse. - Ho, Guildenstern!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Oh, Gertrude, let's go. As soon as the sun sets we'll ship him off to England. It'll take all my diplomatic know-how to explain and excuse the murder he's committed. Hey, Guildenstern!

paragraphs.original:
Enter ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN enter.
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
Friends both, go join you with some further aid.
Hamlet in madness hath Polonius slain,
And from his mother's closet hath he dragged him.
Go seek him out, speak fair, and bring the body
Into the chapel. I pray you, haste in this.
paragraphs.translated: My friends, go find others to help you. Hamlet in his madness has killed Polonius and dragged him out of his mother's bedroom. Go find him and speak nicely to him, and bring the corpse into the chapel. Please hurry.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
Come, Gertrude, we'll call up our wisest friends,
And let them know both what we mean to do
And what's untimely done. So dreaded slander - 
Whose whisper o'er the world's diameter,
As level as the cannon to his blank,
Transports the poisoned shot - may miss our name
And hit the woundless air. Oh, come away!
My soul is full of discord and dismay.
paragraphs.translated: Come, Gertrude. We'll confer with our wisest friends and tell them what we're going to do, and what terrible deed has been done already. Let's hope slander - a bullet that can travel halfway around the world and still hit its exact target - spares us. Oh, we must go. I'm full of confusion and despair.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET enters.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Safely stowed.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
The body is safely hidden.

paragraphs.original:
GENTLEMEN
(from within) Hamlet! Lord Hamlet!
(from within)
paragraphs.translated:
GENTLEMEN
(from offstage) Hamlet, Lord Hamlet!
(from offstage)

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
But soft, what noise? Who calls on Hamlet?
Oh, here they come.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What's that noise? Who's calling for Hamlet? Oh, here they come.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and others
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN enter with others.
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
What have you done, my lord, with the dead body?
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
What have you done with the corpse, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Compounded it with dust, whereto 'tis kin.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I've gotten it dirty - ashes to ashes, and dust to dust.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Tell us where 'tis, that we may take it thence
And bear it to the chapel.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
But tell us where it is, so we can take it to the chapel.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Do not believe it.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Don't believe it.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Believe what?
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
Believe what?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
That I can keep your counsel and not mine own. Besides, to be demanded of a sponge! What replication should be made by the son of a king?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That I'd take your advice rather than keep my own secret. Besides, you're a sponge! What is the son of a king supposed to say to a sponge?

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Take you me for a sponge, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
You think I'm a sponge, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Ay, sir, that soaks up the king's countenance, his rewards, his authorities. But such officers do the king best service in the end. He keeps them, like an ape, in the corner of his jaw, first mouthed to be last swallowed. When he needs what you have gleaned, it is but squeezing you and, sponge, you shall be dry again.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Yes, sir, a sponge that soaks up the king's approval, his rewards, and his decisions. Officers like that give the king the best service in the end. He keeps them in his mouth like an ape. First he moves them around, then he swallows them. When he needs what you have found out, he can just squeeze you like a sponge and you'll be dry again.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
I understand you not, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
I don't follow, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I am glad of it. A knavish speech sleeps in a foolish ear.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'm glad about that. Sly words are never understood by fools.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
My lord, you must tell us where the body is and go with us to the king.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
My lord, you have to tell us where the body is, and then go with us to see the king.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
The body is with the king, but the king is not with the body.
The king is a thing -
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
The body's with the king, but the king's not with the body. The king's a thing …

paragraphs.original:
GUILDENSTERN
A thing, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN
A "thing," my lord?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Of nothing. Bring me to him. Hide, fox, and all after.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A thing of no importance. Take me to him. Ready or not, here I come!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter King CLAUDIUS and two or three attendants
CLAUDIUS
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS enters with two or three of his attendants.
CLAUDIUS

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
I have sent to seek him and to find the body.
How dangerous is it that this man goes loose!
Yet must not we put the strong law on him.
He's loved of the distracted multitude,
Who like not in their judgment, but their eyes.
And where 'tis so, th' offender's scourge is weighed,
But never the offense. To bear all smooth and even,
This sudden sending him away must seem
Deliberate pause. Diseases desperate grown
By desperate appliance are relieved,
Or not at all.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
I've sent men to find him and retrieve the body. How dangerous to have this madman on the loose! But we can't throw him in jail. The people love him, because they judge based on appearance rather than reason. They'll pay attention to the severity of the punishment, not the severity of the crime. No, we must seem calm and fair-minded, and our sending him away must seem like a carefully considered move. But a terminal disease requires extreme treatment, or nothing at all.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ROSENCRANTZ
ROSENCRANTZ
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ enters.
ROSENCRANTZ

paragraphs.original: How now, what hath befall'n?
paragraphs.translated: So what's happened?

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Where the dead body is bestowed, my lord,
We cannot get from him.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
We can't get him to tell us where he's put the body.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
But where is he?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
But where is he?

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Without, my lord; guarded, to know your pleasure.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
Outside, my lord, under guard, waiting for your orders.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Bring him before us.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Bring him to me.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Ho, Guildenstern! Bring in my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
Hey, Guildenstern! Bring in my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET and GUILDENSTERN
HAMLET
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
GUILDENSTERN enters with HAMLET.
GUILDENSTERN
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Now, Hamlet, where's Polonius?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Now, Hamlet, where's Polonius?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
At supper.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
At dinner.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
At supper where?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
At dinner where?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Not where he eats, but where he is eaten. A certain convocation of politic worms are e'en at him. Your worm is your only emperor for diet. We fat all creatures else to fat us, and we fat ourselves for maggots. Your fat king and your lean beggar is but variable service - two dishes, but to one table. That's the end.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Not where he's eating, but where he's being eaten. A certain
conference of worms is chowing down on him. Worms are the emperor of all diets. We fatten up all creatures to feed ourselves, and we fatten ourselves for the worms to eat when we're dead. A fat king and a skinny beggar are just two dishes at the same meal. That's all I have to say.
conference of worms

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Alas, alas!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Oh no, oh no!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a king, and eat of the fish that hath fed of that worm.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A man can fish with the worm that ate a king, and then eat the fish he catches with that worm.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
What dost you mean by this?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
What do you mean by that?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Nothing but to show you how a king may go a progress through the guts of a beggar.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Nothing much, just to demonstrate that a king can move through the bowels of a beggar.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Where is Polonius?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Where is Polonius?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
In heaven. Send hither to see. If your messenger find him not there, seek him i' th' other place yourself. But if indeed you find him not within this month, you shall nose him as you go up the stairs into the lobby.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
In heaven. Send a messager there if you want to be sure. If your messenger can't find him, you can check hell yourself. But seriously, if you don't find him within the next month, you'll be sure to smell him as you go upstairs into the main hall.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
(to attendants) Go seek him there.
(to attendants)
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
(to attendants) Go look for him there.
(to attendants)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some attendants
paragraphs.translated: Some attendants exit.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
He will stay till ye come.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
No need to hurry, he's not going anywhere.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Hamlet, this deed, for thine especial safety - 
Which we do tender as we dearly grieve
For that which thou hast done - must send thee hence
With fiery quickness. Therefore prepare thyself.
The bark is ready and the wind at help,
Th' associates tend, and everything is bent
For England.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Hamlet, I care for you just as much as I grieve for Polonius. For your own protection, I must send you to England at once. So get ready to leave. The ship is set to sail, the wind is favorable, your servants are waiting for you - everything is ready for you to go to England.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
For England?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
To England?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Ay, Hamlet.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Yes, Hamlet.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Good.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Good.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
So is it, if thou knew'st our purposes.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Yes, you'd think so, if you knew why I was sending you.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I see a cherub that sees them. But come, for England.
Farewell, dear mother.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I know an angel who can read your mind. But okay, off to England! Good-bye, dear mother.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Thy loving father, Hamlet.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
I'm your father, Hamlet - your father who loves you.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
My mother. Father and mother is man and wife, man and wife is one flesh, and so, my mother. - Come, for England!
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
You're my mother. When you married my mother, the two of you became one flesh, so if you're my father you're also my mother. Come on, off to England!

paragraphs.original:
Exit HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Follow him at foot. Tempt him with speed aboard.
Delay it not. I'll have him hence tonight.
Away! For everything is sealed and done
That else leans on the affair. Pray you, make haste.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Follow him on foot, and get him on board as quickly as possible. Don't waste any time. I want him out of here tonight. Go now; everything else is ready. Please hurry.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt all but CLAUDIUS
CLAUDIUS
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except CLAUDIUS exits.
CLAUDIUS

paragraphs.original:
And, England, if my love thou hold'st at aught - 
As my great power thereof may give thee sense,
Since yet thy cicatrice looks raw and red
After the Danish sword and thy free awe
paragraphs.translated: And you, dear king of England, if you care about me at all - and you should, since you can still feel the damage that Denmark has done to you in the past and, so, fear and respect us - then you won't ignore my letters instructing you to kill Hamlet immediately. Do it,

paragraphs.original:
Pays homage to us - thou mayst not coldly set
Our sovereign process, which imports at full,
By letters congruing to that effect,
The present death of Hamlet. Do it, England,
For like the hectic in my blood he rages,
And thou must cure me. Till I know 'tis done,
Howe'er my haps, my joys were ne'er begun.
paragraphs.translated: English king, since he's raging like a fever in my brain, and you must cure me. Until I know it's been done, I'll never be happy, no matter how much luck I have.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter FORTINBRAS with his army and a CAPTAIN
FORTINBRAS
CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated:
FORTINBRAS enters with his army and a CAPTAIN.
FORTINBRAS
CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original:
FORTINBRAS
Go, Captain, from me greet the Danish king
Tell him that, by his license, Fortinbras
Craves the conveyance of a promised march
Over his kingdom. You know the rendezvous.
If that his majesty would aught with us,
We shall express our duty in his eye,
And let him know so.
paragraphs.translated:
FORTINBRAS
Go, Captain, and give the Danish king my greetings. Tell him that Fortinbras asks permission to move his troops across Denmark. You know the meeting place we've arranged. If His Majesty wants us to do any favor for him, tell him his wish is my command.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
I will do 't, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
I'll tell him, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
FORTINBRAS
Go softly on.
paragraphs.translated:
FORTINBRAS
Go ahead, then.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt all except the CAPTAIN
CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except the CAPTAIN exits.
CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and others
HAMLET
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and others enter.
HAMLET
ROSENCRANTZ
GUILDENSTERN

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Good sir, whose powers are these?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Sir, whose troops are these?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
They are of Norway, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
The king of Norway's, sir.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How purposed, sir, I pray you?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What are they doing here, sir?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Against some part of Poland.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
They're on their way to invade some part of Poland.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Who commands them, sir?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Who's commanding them, sir?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
The nephew to old Norway, Fortinbras.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
The nephew of the old king of Norway, Fortinbras.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Goes it against the main of Poland, sir,
Or for some frontier?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Is he attacking the heartland of Poland or some frontier?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Truly to speak, and with no addition,
We go to gain a little patch of ground
That hath in it no profit but the name.
To pay five ducats, five, I would not farm it.
Nor will it yield to Norway or the Pole
A ranker rate, should it be sold in fee.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
To tell the truth, we're fighting to win a little patch of ground that's not worth anything. I myself wouldn't pay five ducats for it, if someone offered it to me to farm. And it won't provide any more profits than that to either the Norwegian or the Pole.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, then the Polack never will defend it.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
So then the Poles won't be willing to defend it.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Yes, it is already garrisoned.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
Oh, yes they will. They've already stationed troops there.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Two thousand souls and twenty thousand ducats
Will not debate the question of this straw.
This is th' impostume of much wealth and peace,
That inward breaks and shows no cause without
Why the man dies. - I humbly thank you, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(to himself) Even two thousand men and twenty-thousand ducats are just the beginning of what it will cost to settle this pointless matter. This is what happens when countries have too much money and peace. This quarrel is like an abcess that grows inside someone until it bursts and kills them, and no one knows why. (to the CAPTAIN) Thank you very much for the information, sir.
to himself
to the

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
God be wi' you, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
Good-bye, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Exit CAPTAIN
CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated:
The CAPTAIN exits.
CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ
Will 't please you go, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ
Will you please come now, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I'll be with you straight. Go a little before.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'll be there in a minute. Start without me.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt all except HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
How all occasions do inform against me,
And spur my dull revenge! What is a man
If his chief good and market of his time
Be but to sleep and feed? A beast, no more.
Sure, he that made us with such large discourse,
Looking before and after, gave us not
That capability and godlike reason
To fust in us unused. Now, whether it be
Bestial oblivion, or some craven scruple
paragraphs.translated: My God! Everything I see shows me how wrong I am and tells me to hurry up and get on with my revenge. What is a human being if he just eats and sleeps? Nothing more than a beast. God didn't create us with such a huge power of thought and a divine capacity for reason in order for us not to use them. Now, whether it's animal-like mindlessness, or the cowardly hesitation

paragraphs.original:
Of thinking too precisely on th' event - 
A thought which, quartered, hath but one part wisdom
And ever three parts coward - I do not know
Why yet I live to say "This thing's to do,"
Sith I have cause and will and strength and means
To do 't. Examples gross as earth exhort me.
Witness this army of such mass and charge
Led by a delicate and tender prince,
Whose spirit with divine ambition puffed
Makes mouths at the invisible event,
Exposing what is mortal and unsure
To all that fortune, death, and danger dare,
Even for an eggshell. Rightly to be great
Is not to stir without great argument,
But greatly to find quarrel in a straw
When honor's at the stake. How stand I then,
That have a father killed, a mother stained,
Excitements of my reason and my blood,
And let all sleep - while, to my shame, I see
The imminent death of twenty thousand men,
That for a fantasy and trick of fame
Go to their graves like beds, fight for a plot
Whereon the numbers cannot try the cause,
Which is not tomb enough and continent
To hide the slain? Oh, from this time forth,
My thoughts be bloody, or be nothing worth!
paragraphs.translated: that comes from thinking too much (thinking thoughts that are one part wisdom, three parts cowardice), I don't know why I'm still alive to say "I have to do this deed" rather than having done it already. I have the motivation, the willpower, the ability, and the means to do it. It's as plain as the ground beneath my feet that I must do it. Look at this massive army led by a delicate and tender prince who's so puffed up with divine ambition that he puts his fragile life at risk, exposing it to danger and death, for a reason as thin as an eggshell. To be truly great doesn't mean you'd only fight for a good reason. It means you'd fight over nothing if your honor was at stake. So where does that leave me, whose father has been murdered and mother defiled, ignoring these mental and emotional provocations and letting well enough alone? Meanwhile, to my shame, I watch twenty thousand men go marching to their deaths for an illusion and a little bit of fame, fighting for a tiny piece of land not even big enough to bury them all. From now on, if my thoughts aren't violent I'll consider them worthless.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HORATIO, GERTRUDE, and a GENTLEMAN
HORATIO
GERTRUDE
GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO, GERTRUDE, and a GENTLEMAN enter.
HORATIO
GERTRUDE
GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
I will not speak with her.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
I won't speak to her.

paragraphs.original:
GENTLEMAN
She is importunate,
Indeed distract. Her mood will needs be pitied.
paragraphs.translated:
GENTLEMAN
She's insistent. In fact, she's crazed. You can't help feeling sorry for her.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
What would she have?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
What does she want?

paragraphs.original:
GENTLEMAN
She speaks much of her father, says she hears
There's tricks i' th' world, and hems, and beats her heart,
Spurns enviously at straws, speaks things in doubt
That carry but half sense. Her speech is nothing,
Yet the unshaped use of it doth move
The hearers to collection. They aim at it,
And botch the words up fit to their own thoughts,
Which, as her winks and nods and gestures yield them,
Indeed would make one think there might be thought,
Though nothing sure, yet much unhappily.
paragraphs.translated:
GENTLEMAN
She talks about her father a lot, and says she hears there are conspiracies around the world, and coughs, and beats her breast, and gets angry over tiny matters, and talks nonsense. Her words don't mean anything, but her babbling causes her listeners to draw conclusions. They hear what they want to hear. Her winks and nods and gestures do suggest that she means to convey a message, and not a happy one.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
'Twere good she were spoken with, for she may strew
Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
It's a good idea to speak to her, since she might lead those with evil intentions to dangerous conclusions.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Let her come in.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Show her in.

paragraphs.original:
Exit GENTLEMAN
GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated:
The GENTLEMAN exits.
GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original:
(aside) To my sick soul (as sin's true nature is)
(aside)
Each toy seems prologue to some great amiss.
So full of artless jealousy is guilt,
It spills itself in fearing to be spilt.
paragraphs.translated:
(to herself) To my sick soul (since sin is always a sickness), every detail looks like an omen of disaster to come. Guilt makes you so full of stupid suspicions that you give yourself away because you're trying so hard not to.
(to herself)

paragraphs.original:
Enter OPHELIA, distracted
OPHELIA
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA enters, insane.
OPHELIA

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Where is the beauteous majesty of Denmark?
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
Where is the beautiful queen of Denmark?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
How now, Ophelia?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
What are you doing, Ophelia?

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
How should I your true love know
How should I your true love know
From another one?
From another one?
By his cockle hat and staff,
By his cockle hat and staff
And his sandal shoon.
And his sandal shoon
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
How can you tell the difference
How can you tell the difference
Between your true lover and some other?
Between your true lover and some other?
Your true one wears a pilgrim's hat
Your true one wears a pilgrim's hat
And a pilgrim's sandals and staff.
And a pilgrim's sandals and staff

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alas, sweet lady, what imports this song?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh heavens, what does that song mean, my dear?

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Say you? Nay, pray you, mark.
(sings)
(sings)
He is dead and gone, lady,
He is dead and gone, lady
He is dead and gone,
He is dead and gone
At his head a grass-green turf,
At his head a grass-green turf
At his heels a stone.
At his heels a stone
Oh, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
I'm sorry, did you say something? Please just listen.
(sings)
(sings)
He is dead and gone, lady,
He is dead and gone, lady
He is dead and gone.
He is dead and gone
At his head is a patch of green grass,
At his head is a patch of green grass
And at his feet there is a tomb stone.
And at his feet there is a tomb stone
Oh, ho!

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Nay, but, Ophelia -
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
No, Ophelia -

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Pray you, mark.
(sings)
(sings)
White his shroud as the mountain snow - 
White his shroud as the mountain snow
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
Just listen, please.
(sings)
(sings)
His death shroud was as white as snow - 
His death shroud was as white as snow -

paragraphs.original:
Enter CLAUDIUS
CLAUDIUS
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS enters.
CLAUDIUS

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alas, look here, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
My lord, look at this poor girl.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
Larded all with sweet flowers,
Larded all with sweet flowers
Which bewept to the ground did not go
Which bewept to the ground did not go
With true-love showers.
With true-love showers
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
Covered with sweet flowers
Covered with sweet flowers
Which did not fall to the ground
Which did not fall to the ground
In true-love showers.
In true-love showers

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
How do you, pretty lady?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
How are you doing, my pretty lady?

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Well, God'ield you! They say the owl was a baker's daughter. Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be. God be at your table.
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
I'm quite well, and may God give you what you deserve. They say the baker's daughter was turned into an owl for refusing Jesus' bread. My lord, we know what we are now, but not what we may become. May God be at your table.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Conceit upon her father.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
She's talking about her dead father.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Pray you, let's have no words of this, but when they ask you what it means, say you this:
(sings)
(sings)
Tomorrow is Saint Valentine's day,
Tomorrow is Saint Valentine's day
All in the morning betime,
All in the morning betime
And I a maid at your window,
And I a maid at your window
To be your Valentine.
To be your Valentine
Then up he rose, and donned his clothes,
Then up he rose, and donned his clothes
And dupped the chamber door.
And dupped the chamber door
Let in the maid that out a maid
Let in the maid that out a maid
Never departed more.
Never departed more
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
Oh, let's not talk about that, but when they ask you what it means, just say:
(sings)
(sings)
Tomorrow is St. Valentine's Day
Tomorrow is St. Valentine's Day
And early in the morning
And early in the morning
I'm a girl below your window
I'm a girl below your window
Waiting to be your Valentine.
Waiting to be your Valentine
Then he got up and put on his clothes
Then he got up and put on his clothes
And opened the door to his room.
And opened the door to his room
He let in the girl, and when she left
He let in the girl, and when she left
She wasn't a virgin anymore.
She wasn't a virgin anymore

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Pretty Ophelia -
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Pretty Ophelia -

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
Indeed, without an oath I'll make an end on 't:
(sings)
(sings)
By Gis and by Saint Charity,
By Gis and by Saint Charity
Alack, and fie, for shame!
Alack, and fie, for shame!
Young men will do 't, if they come to 't.
Young men will do 't, if they come to 't
By Cock, they are to blame.
By Cock, they are to blame
Quoth she, "Before you tumbled me,
Quoth she, "Before you tumbled me
You promised me to wed."
You promised me to wed."
He answers,
He answers
"So would I ha' done, by yonder sun,
"So would I ha' done, by yonder sun
An thou hadst not come to my bed."
An thou hadst not come to my bed."
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
Hang on, I'll end it soon, I promise:
(sings)
(sings)
By the name of Jesus and Saint Charity,
By the name of Jesus and Saint Charity
My goodness, what a shame it is,
My goodness, what a shame it is
Young men will do it if they get a chance:
Young men will do it if they get a chance:
By God, they're very bad.
By God, they're very bad
She said, "Before you got me into bed,
She said, "Before you got me into bed
You promised to marry me."
You promised to marry me."
He answers:
He answers:
"I would have married you, I swear,
"I would have married you, I swear
If you hadn't gone to bed with me."
If you hadn't gone to bed with me."

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
How long hath she been thus?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
How long has she been like this?

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
I hope all will be well. We must be patient, but I cannot choose but weep, to think they should lay him i' th' cold ground. My brother shall know of it, and so I thank you for your good counsel. Come, my coach! Good night, ladies. Good night, sweet ladies. Good night, good night.
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
I hope everything will turn out fine. We must be patient, but I can't help crying when I think of him being laid in the cold ground. My brother will hear about this. And so I thank you for your good advice. Come, driver! Good night, ladies, good night, sweet ladies, good night, good night.

paragraphs.original:
Exit OPHELIA
OPHELIA
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA exits.
OPHELIA

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Follow her close. Give her good watch, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Follow her. Keep an eye on her, please.

paragraphs.original:
Exit HORATIO
HORATIO
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO exits.
HORATIO

paragraphs.original:
Oh, this is the poison of deep grief. It springs
All from her father's death, and now behold!
O Gertrude, Gertrude,
When sorrows come, they come not single spies
But in battalions. First, her father slain.
Next, your son gone, and he most violent author
Of his own just remove. The people muddied,
Thick, and unwholesome in their thoughts and whispers
For good Polonius' death, and we have done but greenly
In hugger-mugger to inter him. Poor Ophelia
Divided from herself and her fair judgment,
Without the which we are pictures, or mere beasts.
Last - and as much containing as all these - 
Her brother is in secret come from France,
Feeds on his wonder, keeps himself in clouds,
And wants not buzzers to infect his ear
With pestilent speeches of his father's death,
Wherein necessity, of matter beggared,
Will nothing stick our person to arraign
In ear and ear. O my dear Gertrude, this,
Like to a murdering piece, in many places
Gives me superfluous death.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, her grief has poisoned her mind. Her father died and now look at her! Oh, Gertrude, Gertrude, when bad things happen, they don't come one at a time, like enemy spies, but all at once like an army. First her father was killed, then your son was taken away - because of his own violent actions. The people are confused and spreading nasty rumors about Polonius's death, and I was a fool to bury him in a hurry, without a proper state funeral. Poor Ophelia has been robbed of her sanity, without which we're just pictures, or animals. Last but not least, her brother has secretly returned from France and is surrounded by gossip-mongers, who fill his ears with wicked stories about his father's death. Deprived of proper evidence, he'll naturally attribute the murder to me. Oh, dear Gertrude, I feel as though I'm being murdered many times over.

paragraphs.original: A noise within
paragraphs.translated: A noise offstage.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Alack, what noise is this?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh, no - what's that noise?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Where are my Switzers? Let them guard the door.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Listen! Where are my bodyguards? Let them guard the door.

paragraphs.original:
Enter a MESSENGER
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
A MESSENGER enters.
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: What is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What is it?

paragraphs.original:
MESSENGER
Save yourself, my lord.
The ocean, overpeering of his list,
Eats not the flats with more impiteous haste
Than young Laertes, in a riotous head,
O'erbears your officers. The rabble call him "lord"
And - as the world were now but to begin,
Antiquity forgot, custom not known,
The ratifiers and props of every word - 
They cry, "Choose we! Laertes shall be king!"
Caps, hands, and tongues applaud it to the clouds:
"Laertes shall be king, Laertes king!"
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER
You must save yourself, my lord. The young Laertes, like the ocean when it floods the shore and devours the lowlands, is leading a rebellion against your government. The crowd calls him "lord" and shouts, "We want Laertes to be king!" It's as if they were starting the world from scratch right now, throwing out the traditions and ancient customs that are the support of every word we utter. They throw their caps in the air and yell, "Laertes will be king! Laertes king!"

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
How cheerfully on the false trail they cry.
O, this is counter, you false Danish dogs!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
They sound so cheerful as they hunt down the wrong prey! Oh, you're on the wrong track, you disloyal Danish dogs!

paragraphs.original: Noise within
paragraphs.translated: A noise offstage.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
The doors are broke.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
The doors have been smashed open.

Enter LAERTES with others
LAERTES

LAERTES

LAERTES
Where is this king? - Sirs, stand you all without.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Where's this so-called king? Men, wait outside.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
No, let's come in!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
No, let us in!

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
I pray you, give me leave.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Please wait.

paragraphs.original:
ALL

paragraphs.translated:
ALL
All right, we will, we will.

FOLLOWERS

LAERTES
FOLLOWERS

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
I thank you. Keep the door. - O thou vile king,
Give me my father!
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Thank you. Guard the door. (to CLAUDIUS) Oh, you vile king, give me my father!
to

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Calmly, good Laertes.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Calm down, good Laertes.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
That drop of blood that's calm proclaims me bastard,
Cries "Cuckold!" to my father, brands the "harlot"
Even here between the chaste unsmirchèd brow
Of my true mother.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I've got exactly one calm drop of blood in my body, and it proclaims that
I'm a bastard, says my father was betrayed, and stamps the label "whore" on the pure forehead of my devoted mother.
I'm a bastard

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
What is the cause, Laertes,
That thy rebellion looks so giant-like? - 
Let him go, Gertrude. Do not fear our person.
There's such divinity doth hedge a king
That treason can but peep to what it would,
Acts little of his will. - Tell me, Laertes,
Why thou art thus incensed. - Let him go, Gertrude. - 
Speak, man.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, what makes you so rebellious? Let him go, Gertrude. Don't worry about my getting hurt. God protects the king, so traitors can't hurt him. - Tell me, Laertes, why you're so angry. - Gertrude, let him go. - Tell me, man.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Where is my father?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Where's my father?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Dead.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
He's dead.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
