But not by him.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
But the king didn't kill him.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Let him demand his fill.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Let him ask what he wants to ask.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
How came he dead? I'll not be juggled with.
To hell, allegiance! Vows, to the blackest devil!
Conscience and grace, to the profoundest pit!
I dare damnation. To this point I stand
That both the worlds I give to negligence.
Let come what comes, only I'll be revenged
Most thoroughly for my father.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
How did he end up dead? Don't mess with me. To hell with my vows of allegiance to you! Vows can go to hell! Conscience, too! I don't care if I'm damned. I don't care what happens to me in this world or the next. Whatever happens, happens, but I'll get revenge for my father's murder.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Who shall stay you?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Who's stopping you?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
My will, not all the world.
And for my means, I'll husband them so well,
They shall go far with little.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Only my free will - nothing else. What little means I have, I'll use against you.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Good Laertes,
If you desire to know the certainty
Of your dear father's death, is 't writ in your revenge,
That, swoopstake, you will draw both friend and foe,
Winner and loser?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
My dear Laertes, in your eagerness to know the truth about your father's death, are you determined to hurt your father's friends and enemies alike?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
None but his enemies.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
No, only his enemies.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Will you know them then?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Do you want to know who they are, then?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
To his good friends thus wide I'll ope my arms
And, like the kind life-rendering pelican,
Repast them with my blood.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I'll open my arms wide to his true friends, and like a mother
pelican with her brood, I'll even give my life for them.
pelican

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Why, now you speak
Like a good child and a true gentleman.
That I am guiltless of your father's death
And am most sensible in grief for it,
It shall as level to your judgment pierce
As day does to your eye.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Why, now you're talking like a good son and a true gentleman. I'll prove to you as clearly as daylight that I'm innocent of your father's death, and am struck with grief over it.

paragraphs.original: Noise within: "Let her come in!"
paragraphs.translated: A voice offstage, "Let her in!"

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
How now? What noise is that?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
What's that noise?

paragraphs.original:
Enter OPHELIA
OPHELIA
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA enters.
OPHELIA

paragraphs.original:
O heat, dry up my brains! Tears seven times salt,
Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!
By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight,
Till our scale turn the beam. O rose of May,
Dear maid, kind sister, sweet Ophelia!
O heavens, is 't possible a young maid's wits
Should be as mortal as an old man's life?
Nature is fine in love, and where 'tis fine,
It sends some precious instance of itself
After the thing it loves.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, heat, dry up my brains! Salty tears, burn my eyes! By heaven, I'll get revenge for your madness! Oh, you springtime rose, dear maiden, kind sister, sweet Ophelia! Is it possible that a young woman's mind could fade away as easily as an old man's life? Human nature is refined and thoughtful - person graciously gives a valuable part of herself away to her beloved, as Ophelia has sent off her sanity to her dead father.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
They bore him barefaced on the bier,
They bore him barefaced on the bier
Hey, non nonny, nonny, hey, nonny,
Hey, non nonny, nonny, hey, nonny
And in his grave rained many a tear.
And in his grave rained many a tear
Fare you well, my dove.
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
They carried him uncovered in the coffin,
They carried him uncovered in the coffin
Hey non nonny, nonny, hey nonny.
Hey non nonny, nonny, hey nonny
And tears poured down into his grave.
And tears poured down into his grave
Good-bye, honey.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade revenge,
It could not move thus.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
If you were sane and could urge me to take revenge, you couldn't be more persuasive than you are now.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
You must sing A-down a-down - And you, Call him a- down-a - Oh, how the wheel becomes it! It is the false steward that stole his master's daughter.
A-down a-down
Call him a-
down-a
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
You're supposed to sing, "A down a-down," and you, "Call him a-down-a." Oh, how it turns around like a wheel! Like the worker who stole his boss's daughter.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
This nothing's more than matter.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
This nonsense means more than rational speech.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
There's rosemary, that's for remembrance. Pray you, love, remember. And there is pansies, that's for thoughts.
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
Look at my flowers. There's rosemary, that's for remembering. Please remember, love. And there are pansies, they're for thoughts.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
A document in madness. Thoughts and remembrance fitted.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
A case study in madness, to connect memory and thought.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
There's fennel for you, and columbines. - There's rue for you, and here's some for me. We may call it "herb of grace" o' Sundays. - Oh, you must wear your rue with a difference. - There's a daisy. I would give you some violets, but they withered all when my father died. They say he made a good end (sings) For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy - 
(sings) For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
(to GERTRUDE ) Here are fennel and columbines for you - they symbolize adultery. (to CLAUDIUS) And here's rue for you - it symbolizes repentance. We can call it the merciful Sunday flower. You should wear it for a different reason. And here's a daisy, for unhappy love. I'd give you some violets, flowers of faithfulness, but they all dried up when my father died. They say he looked good when he died. (sings) For good sweet Robin is all my joy.
(to
)
(to
)
(sings) For good sweet Robin is all my joy

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Thought and affliction, passion, hell itself,
She turns to favor and to prettiness.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Sadness and torment, suffering, hell itself - she makes them almost pretty.

paragraphs.original:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
And will he not come again?
And will he not come again?
And will he not come again?
And will he not come again?
No, no, he is dead,
No, no, he is dead
Go to thy deathbed.
Go to thy deathbed
He never will come again.
He never will come again
His beard was as white as snow,
His beard was as white as snow
All flaxen was his poll.
All flaxen was his poll
He is gone, he is gone,
He is gone, he is gone
And we cast away moan,
And we cast away moan
God ha' mercy on his soul. - 
God ha' mercy on his soul
And of all Christian souls, I pray God. God be wi' ye.
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA
(sings)
(sings)
And won't he come again?
And won't he come again?
And won't he come again?
And won't he come again?
No, no, he's dead.
No, no, he's dead
Go to your deathbed.
Go to your deathbed
He'll never come again.
He'll never come again
His beard was white as snow,
His beard was white as snow,
His hair was all white too.
His hair was all white too
He's gone, he's gone,
He's gone, he's gone
And we moan as we're cast away.
And we moan as we're cast away
God have mercy on his soul.
God have mercy on his soul
And on the souls of all good Christians, I hope. Goodbye, God be with you.

paragraphs.original:
Exit OPHELIA
OPHELIA
paragraphs.translated:
OPHELIA exits.
OPHELIA

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Do you see this, O God?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Do you see this, oh, God?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, I must commune with your grief,
Or you deny me right. Go but apart,
Make choice of whom your wisest friends you will.
And they shall hear and judge 'twixt you and me.
If by direct or by collateral hand
They find us touched, we will our kingdom give,
Our crown, our life, and all that we can ours,
To you in satisfaction. But if not,
Be you content to lend your patience to us,
And we shall jointly labor with your soul
To give it due content.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, I have a right to share your grief. Go choose your wisest friends, and have them listen to both of us and decide which of us is right. If directly or indirectly they find me implicated in your father's murder, I'll give up my kingdom, my crown, my life, and everything I call my own to you as restitution. But if they find me innocent, then be patient and I'll work to satisfy to the fullest extent your deepest need for revenge.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Let this be so.
His means of death, his obscure funeral - 
No trophy, sword, nor hatchment o'er his bones,
No noble rite nor formal ostentation - 
Cry to be heard as 'twere from heaven to earth,
That I must call 't in question.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
All right, then. The way he died, his secret funeral, no funeral rites or military display, no noble rites or formal ceremony - shout out from heaven and earth that I must call the way he died into question.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
So you shall.
And where the offense is, let the great ax fall.
I pray you, go with me.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
And you're right to do so. May the guilty party be punished by death. Please, come with me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HORATIO and a SERVANT
HORATIO
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO and a SERVANT enter.
HORATIO
SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
What are they that would speak with me?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Who are the people who want to speak with me?

paragraphs.original:
SERVANT
Seafaring men, sir. They say they have letters for you.
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT
Sailors, sir. They say they have letters for you.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Let them come in.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Show them in.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT exits.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
I do not know from what part of the world
I should be greeted, if not from Lord Hamlet.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know who else would send me a letter from abroad except Hamlet.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SAILORS
SAILORS
paragraphs.translated:
SAILORS enter.
SAILORS

paragraphs.original:
SAILOR
God bless you, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
SAILOR
Hello, sir. God bless you.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Let him bless thee too.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
May He bless you, too.

paragraphs.original:
SAILOR
He shall, sir, an 't please Him. There's a letter for you, sir -  it comes from the ambassador that was bound for England - if your name be Horatio, as I am let to know it is. (gives HORATIO a letter)
(gives
a letter)
paragraphs.translated:
SAILOR
He will, sir, if He wants to. There's a letter for you, sir. It's from the ambassador, Lord Hamlet, who was going to England - if your name's Horatio, as they told me it is. (he hands HORATIO a letter)
(he hands
a letter)

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
(reads)
(reads)
"Horatio,
When thou shalt have overlooked this, give these fellows some means to the king. They have letters for him. Ere we were two days old at sea, a pirate of very warlike appointment gave us chase. Finding ourselves too slow of sail, we put on a compelled valor, and in the grapple I boarded them. On the instant, they got clear of our ship, so I alone became their prisoner. They have dealt with me like thieves of mercy, but they knew what they did; I am to do a good turn for them.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
(reading the letter)
(reading the letter)
"Horatio,
When you've read this letter, find a way to let these guys see the king. They have letters for him. Before we were at sea for even two days, a pirate ship equipped for battle pursued us. We were too slow to escape, so we were forced to stand and fight. In the battle that followed I ended up on the pirate ship. Just then they left our ship behind, so I became the only prisoner on board. They've treated me quite mercifully for thieves, but they knew what they were doing. They want me to do a favor for them.

paragraphs.original:
Let the king have the letters I have sent, and repair thou to me with as much speed as thou wouldst fly death. I have words to speak in thine ear will make thee dumb, yet are they much too light for the bore of the matter. These good fellows will bring thee where I am. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern hold their course for England. Of them I have much to tell thee. Fare-well.
He that thou knowest thine,
Hamlet."
Come, I will give you way for these your letters, And do 't the speedier, that you may direct me To him from whom you brought them.
paragraphs.translated:
Give the king the letters I've sent, and come to me as fast as you would run from death. I've got things to tell you that will make you speechless, and they aren't even half the story. These guys will take you to me. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are on their way to England. I have a lot to tell you about them. Good-bye.
Your trusted friend,
Hamlet."
Come, men. I'll show you where to deliver these letters as quickly as possible, so that you can take me to the man who sent them.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter CLAUDIUS and LAERTES
CLAUDIUS
LAERTES
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS and LAERTES enter.
CLAUDIUS
LAERTES

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal,
And you must put me in your heart for friend,
Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear,
That he which hath your noble father slain
Pursued my life.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Now you've got to acknowledge my innocence and believe I'm your friend, since you've heard and understood that the man who killed your father was trying to kill me.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
It well appears. But tell me
Why you proceeded not against these feats,
So criminal and so capital in nature,
As by your safety, wisdom, all things else,
You mainly were stirred up.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
It looks that way. But tell me why you didn't take immediate action against his criminal acts, when your own safety and everything else would seem to call for it.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Oh, for two special reasons,
Which may to you perhaps seem much unsinewed,
But yet to me they are strong. The queen his mother
Lives almost by his looks, and for myself - 
My virtue or my plague, be it either which - 
She's so conjunctive to my life and soul,
That, as the star moves not but in his sphere,
I could not but by her. The other motive
Why to a public count I might not go,
Is the great love the general gender bear him,
Who, dipping all his faults in their affection,
Would, like the spring that turneth wood to stone,
Convert his gyves to graces - so that my arrows,
Too slightly timbered for so loud a wind,
Would have reverted to my bow again,
And not where I had aimed them.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Oh, for two main reasons which may seem weak to you, but strong to me. The queen, his mother, is devoted to him. And (for better or worse, whichever it is) she is such a part of my life and soul that I can't live apart from her, any more than a planet can leave its orbit. The other reason why I couldn't prosecute and arrest Hamlet is that the public loves him. In their affection they overlook all his faults. Like magic, they convert them into virtues, so whatever I said against him would end up hurting me, not him.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
And so have I a noble father lost,
A sister driven into desperate terms,
Whose worth, if praises may go back again,
Stood challenger on mount of all the age
For her perfections. But my revenge will come.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
And so I've lost my noble father, had my sister driven insane - my sister who once was (if I can praise her for what she once was, not what she is now) the most perfect girl who ever lived. But I'll get my revenge.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Break not your sleeps for that. You must not think
That we are made of stuff so flat and dull
That we can let our beard be shook with danger
And think it pastime. You shortly shall hear more.
I loved your father, and we love ourself.
And that, I hope, will teach you to imagine -
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Don't you worry about that. You must not think that I'm so lazy and dull that I can be severely threatened and think it's just a game. You'll hear more about my plans soon enough. I loved your father, and I love myself, which should be enough to -

paragraphs.original:
Enter a MESSENGER
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
A MESSENGER enters with letters.
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: How now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: What is it? What's the news?

paragraphs.original:
MESSENGER
Letters, my lord, from Hamlet.
This to your majesty, this to the queen. (gives CLAUDIUS letters)
(gives
letters)
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER
Letters, my lord, from Hamlet. This one's for Your Highness, this one for the queen. (gives CLAUDIUS letters)
(gives
letters)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
From Hamlet? Who brought them?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
From Hamlet? Who delivered them?

paragraphs.original:
MESSENGER
Sailors, my lord, they say. I saw them not.
They were given me by Claudio. He received them
Of him that brought them.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER
Sailors, my lord, or so they say. I didn't see them. Claudio gave them to me, and he got them from the one who delivered them.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, you shall hear them. - Leave us.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, I want you to hear what they say. Leave us alone now.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MESSENGER
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
The MESSENGER exits.
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original:
(reads)
(reads)
"High and mighty,
You shall know I am set naked on your kingdom. Tomorrow shall I beg leave to see your kingly eyes, when I shall, first asking your pardon thereunto, recount the occasion of my sudden and more strange return.
Hamlet."
paragraphs.translated:
(reads)
(reads)
"High and Mighty one,
You know I've been set down naked, you might say, in your kingdom. Tomorrow I'll beg permission to look into your kingly eyes, at which point I'll tell you the story (after first apologizing) of how I came back to Denmark so strangely and suddenly.
Hamlet"

paragraphs.original: What should this mean? Are all the rest come back? Or is it some abuse, and no such thing?
paragraphs.translated: What does this mean? Has everyone else come back too? Or is it all a lie - and no one has yet returned?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Know you the hand?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Do you recognize the handwriting?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
'Tis Hamlet's character. "Naked"?
And in a postscript here, he says "alone."
Can you advise me?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
It's Hamlet's writing. "Naked," he says. And in a P.S. he adds, "alone." Can you help me out with this?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
I'm lost in it, my lord. But let him come.
It warms the very sickness in my heart
That I shall live and tell him to his teeth,
"Thus diddest thou."
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I have no clue, my lord. But let him come. It warms my weary heart to think I'll get the chance to look him in the eye and say, "You did this."

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
If it be so, Laertes - 
As how should it be so? How otherwise? - 
Will you be ruled by me?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
If that's how you feel, Laertes - and why shouldn't you? Will you let me guide and direct you?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Ay, my lord - 
So you will not o'errule me to a peace.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Yes, my lord, as long as you won't lead me toward peace.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
To thine own peace. If he be now returned,
As checking at his voyage, and that he means
No more to undertake it, I will work him
To an exploit, now ripe in my devise,
Under the which he shall not choose but fall.
And for his death no wind of blame shall breathe,
But even his mother shall uncharge the practice
And call it accident.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
No, just toward your own peace of mind. If he's come back to Denmark without plans to continue on his trip, then I'll trick him into an undertaking, which I'm working out now, that's sure to kill him. When he dies, no one will be blamed, even his mother will call it an accident.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
My lord, I will be ruled
The rather if you could devise it so
That I might be the organ.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
My lord, I'll let you make the decision. I only ask to be in on your plans, the agent of his death.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
It falls right.
You have been talked of since your travel much - 
And that in Hamlet's hearing - for a quality
Wherein, they say, you shine. Your sum of parts
Did not together pluck such envy from him
As did that one, and that, in my regard,
Of the unworthiest siege.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
That'll be fine. Since you left, people have been talking about - and within earshot of Hamlet - a certain quality of yours in which, they say, you shine. All your talents and gifts didn't arouse as much envy from him as this one quality did, though to me it's far from your best attribute.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
What part is that, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
What quality is that, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
A very ribbon in the cap of youth,
Yet needful too, for youth no less becomes
The light and careless livery that it wears
Than settled age his sables and his weeds,
Importing health and graveness. Two months since,
Here was a gentleman of Normandy.
I've seen myself, and served against, the French,
And they can well on horseback. But this gallant
Had witchcraft in 't. He grew unto his seat,
And to such wondrous doing brought his horse
As he had been encorpsed and demi-natured
With the brave beast. So far he topped my thought,
That I, in forgery of shapes and tricks,
Come short of what he did.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
A trivial little ribbon on the cap of youth - yet an important one, too, since casual clothes suit young people as much as serious business suits and overcoats suit the middle-aged. Two months ago I met a gentleman from Normandy. I've fought against the French and have seen how well they ride, but this man was a magician on horseback. It was as if he were part of the horse, so skillful that even having seen him, I can hardly conceive of the tricks he did.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
A Norman was 't?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Hmm, he was from Normandy, you say?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
A Norman.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Yes, from Normandy.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Upon my life, Lamond!
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I bet it was Lamond.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
The very same.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Yes, that's the one.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
I know him well. He is the brooch indeed
And gem of all the nation.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I know him well. He's his homeland's jewel.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
He made confession of you,
And gave you such a masterly report
For art and exercise in your defense,
And for your rapier most especially,
That he cried out 'twould be a sight indeed
If one could match you. The 'scrimers of their nation,
He swore, had had neither motion, guard, nor eye,
If you opposed them. Sir, this report of his
Did Hamlet so envenom with his envy
That he could nothing do but wish and beg
Your sudden coming o'er, to play with him.
Now, out of this -
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
He mentioned you to me, giving you such high marks in fencing that he exclaimed it would be a miracle if someone could match you. French fencers wouldn't be good enough for you, he said, since they don't have the right moves or skills. Hamlet was so jealous when he heard Lamond's report that he talked about nothing else but having you come over and play against him. Now, the point is …

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
What out of this, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
What's the point, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, was your father dear to you?
Or are you like the painting of a sorrow,
A face without a heart?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Laertes, did you love your father? Or is your grief just an illusion - a mere painting of sorrow?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Why ask you this?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
How could you ask?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Not that I think you did not love your father
But that I know love is begun by time,
And that I see, in passages of proof,
Time qualifies the spark and fire of it.
There lives within the very flame of love
A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it.
And nothing is at a like goodness still.
For goodness, growing to a pleurisy,
Dies in his own too-much. That we would do,
We should do when we would, for this "would" changes
And hath abatements and delays as many
As there are tongues, are hands, are accidents.
And then this "should" is like a spendthrift sigh
That hurts by easing. - But to the quick of th' ulcer:
Hamlet comes back. What would you undertake
To show yourself in deed your father's son
More than in words?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Not that I suspect you didn't love your father, but I've seen it happen that, as the days go by, time dampens the flame of love. The fire of love always burns itself out, and nothing stays the way it began. Even a good thing can grow too big and die from its own excess. We should do what we intend to do right when we intend it, since our intentions are subject to as many weakenings and delays as there are words in the dictionary and accidents in life. And then all our "woulds" and "shoulds" are nothing but hot air. But back to my point:

Hamlet's coming back. What proof will you offer - in action, not just words - that you're your father's son?

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
To cut his throat i' th' church.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I'll cut Hamlet's throat in church.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
No place, indeed, should murder sanctuarize.
Revenge should have no bounds. But, good Laertes,
Will you do this, keep close within your chamber.
Hamlet returned shall know you are come home.
We'll put on those shall praise your excellence
And set a double varnish on the fame
The Frenchman gave you, bring you in fine together
And wager on your heads. He, being remiss,
Most generous and free from all contriving,
Will not peruse the foils; so that, with ease,
Or with a little shuffling, you may choose
A sword unbated, and in a pass of practice
Requite him for your father.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
It's true, no place - not even a church - should offer refuge to that murderer. Revenge should have no limits. But Laertes, will you do this: stay in your room? When Hamlet comes home he'll learn you're here. I'll have people praise your excellence and put a double coat on the fame the Frenchman gave you. In short, we'll get you together and place bets on you. Hamlet's so careless, high-minded, and unsuspecting that he won't examine the swords beforehand, so you can easily choose one with a sharpened point and in one thrust avenge the death of your father.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
I will do 't.
And for that purpose I'll anoint my sword.
I bought an unction of a mountebank,
So mortal that, but dip a knife in it,
Where it draws blood no cataplasm so rare,
Collected from all simples that have virtue
Under the moon, can save the thing from death
That is but scratched withal. I'll touch my point
With this contagion, that if I gall him slightly
It may be death.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
I'll do it, and I'll put a little dab of something on my sword as well. From a quack doctor I bought some oil so poisonous that if you dip a knife in it, no medicine in the world can save the person who's scratched by it. If I even graze his skin slightly, he's likely to die.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Let's further think of this,
Weigh what convenience both of time and means
May fit us to our shape. If this should fail,
And that our drift look through our bad performance,
'Twere better not assayed. Therefore this project
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Let's think about this, and consider what time and what method will be most appropriate. If our plan were to fail, and people found out about it, it would be better never to have tried it.
We should have a backup ready in case the first plan doesn't work. Let me think. We'll place bets on you and Hamlet - that's it! When the two of you have gotten all sweaty and hot - keep him jumping around a lot for that purpose - Hamlet will ask for something to drink. I'll have a cup ready for him. If by chance he

paragraphs.original:
Should have a back or second that might hold
If this should blast in proof. - Soft, let me see. - 
We'll make a solemn wager on your cunnings. - 
I ha 't! When in your motion you are hot and dry,
As make your bouts more violent to that end,
And that he calls for drink, I'll have prepared him
A chalice for the nonce, whereon but sipping,
If he by chance escape your venomed stuck,
Our purpose may hold there. - But stay, what noise?
paragraphs.translated: escapes your poisoned sword tip, the drink will kill him. But wait, what's that sound?

paragraphs.original:
Enter GERTRUDE
GERTRUDE
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE enters.
GERTRUDE

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
One woe doth tread upon another's heel,
So fast they follow. - Your sister's drowned, Laertes.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
The bad news just keeps on coming, one disaster after another. Your sister's drowned, Laertes.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Drowned? Oh, where?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Drowned? Oh, where?

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
There is a willow grows aslant a brook
That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream.
There with fantastic garlands did she come
Of crowflowers, nettles, daisies, and long purples,
That liberal shepherds give a grosser name,
But our cold maids do "dead men's fingers" call them.
There, on the pendant boughs her coronet weeds
Clambering to hang, an envious sliver broke,
When down her weedy trophies and herself
Fell in the weeping brook. Her clothes spread wide,
And mermaid-like a while they bore her up,
Which time she chanted snatches of old lauds
As one incapable of her own distress,
Or like a creature native and indued
Unto that element. But long it could not be
Till that her garments, heavy with their drink,
Pulled the poor wretch from her melodious lay
To muddy death.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
There's a willow that leans over the brook, dangling its white leaves over the glassy water. Ophelia made wild wreaths out of those leaves, braiding in crowflowers, thistles, daisies, and the orchises that vulgar shepherds have an obscene name for, but which pure-minded girls call "dead men's fingers." Climbing into the tree to hang the wreath of weeds on the hanging branches, she and her flowers fell into the gurgling brook. Her clothes spread out wide in the water, and buoyed her up for a while as she sang bits of old hymns, acting like someone who doesn't realize the danger she's in, or like someone completely accustomed to danger. But it was only a matter of time before her clothes, heavy with the water they absorbed, pulled the poor thing out of her song, down into the mud at the bottom of the brook.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Alas, then she is drowned.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
So she is drowned.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Drowned, drowned.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Drowned, drowned.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Too much of water hast thou, poor Ophelia,
And therefore I forbid my tears. But yet
It is our trick. Nature her custom holds,
Let shame say what it will. When these are gone,
The woman will be out. - Adieu, my lord.
I have a speech of fire that fain would blaze,
But that this folly doubts it.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
You've had too much water already, poor Ophelia, so I won't shed watery tears for you. But crying is what humans do. We do what's in our nature, even if we're ashamed of it. After I stop crying I'll be through acting like a woman. Good-bye, my lord. I have some fiery words I could speak now, but my foolish tears are drowning them out.

paragraphs.original:
Exit LAERTES
LAERTES
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES exits.
LAERTES

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Let's follow, Gertrude.
How much I had to do to calm his rage!
Now fear I this will give it start again.
Therefore let's follow.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Let's follow him, Gertrude. I worked so hard to calm him down, and now I'm worried he's getting all excited again. Let's follow him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter a GRAVEDIGGER and the OTHER gravedigger
GRAVEDIGGER
OTHER
paragraphs.translated:
A GRAVEDIGGER and the OTHER gravedigger enter.
GRAVEDIGGER
OTHER

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Is she to be buried in Christian burial when she willfully seeks her own salvation?
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Are they really going to give her a Christian burial
after she killed herself?
after she killed herself?

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
I tell thee she is. Therefore make her grave straight. The crowner hath sat on her and finds it Christian burial.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
I'm telling you, yes. So finish that grave right away. The coroner examined her case and says it should be a Christian funeral.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her own defense?
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
But how, unless she drowned in self-defense?

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Why, 'tis found so.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
That's what they're saying she did.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
It must be se offendendo. It cannot be else. For here lies the point: if I drown myself wittingly, it argues an act. And an act hath three branches - it is to act, to do, to perform. Argal, she drowned herself wittingly.
se offendendo
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Sounds more like "self-offense," if you ask me. What I'm saying is, if she knew she was drowning herself, then that's an act. An act has three sides to it: to do, to act, and to perform. Therefore she must have known she was drowning herself.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Nay, but hear you, Goodman Delver -
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
No, listen here, gravedigger sir -

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Give me leave. Here lies the water. Good. Here stands the man. Good. If the man go to this water and drown himself, it is, will he nill he, he goes. Mark you that. But if the water come to him and drown him, he drowns not himself. Argal, he that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Let me finish. Here's the water, right? And here's a man, okay? If the man goes into the water and drowns himself, he's the one doing it, like it or not. But if the water comes to him and drowns him, then he doesn't drown himself. Therefore, he who is innocent of his own death does not shorten his own life.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
But is this law?
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Is that how the law sees it?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Ay, marry, is 't. Crowner's quest law.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
It sure is. The coroner's inquest law.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Will you ha' the truth on 't? If this had not been a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out o' Christian burial.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Do you want to know the truth? If this woman hadn't been rich, she wouldn't have been given a Christian burial.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Why, there thou sayst. And the more pity that great folk should have countenance in this world to drown or hang themselves more than their even Christian. Come, my spade. There is no ancient gentleman but gardeners, ditchers, and grave-makers. They hold up Adam's profession.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Well there, now you've said it. It's a pity that the rich have more freedom to hang or drown themselves than the rest of us Christians. Come on, shovel. The most ancient aristocrats in the world are gardeners, ditch-diggers, and gravediggers. They keep up Adam's profession.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Was he a gentleman?
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Was he an aristocrat? With a coat of arms?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
He was the first that ever bore arms.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
He was the first person who ever had arms.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Why, he had none.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
He didn't have any.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the Scripture? The Scripture says Adam digged. Could he dig without arms? I'll put another question to thee. If thou answerest me not to the purpose, confess thyself -
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
What, aren't you a Christian? The Bible says Adam dug in the ground. How could he dig without arms? I'll ask you another question. If you can't answer it -

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Go to.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Go ahead!

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
What is he that builds stronger than either the mason, the shipwright, or the carpenter?
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
What do you call a person who builds stronger things than a stonemason, a shipbuilder, or a carpenter does?

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
The gallows-maker, for that frame outlives a thousand tenants.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
The one who builds the gallows to hang people on, since his structure outlives a thousand inhabitants.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
I like thy wit well, in good faith. The gallows does well, but how does it well? It does well to those that do ill.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
You're funny, and I like that. The gallows do a good job. But how? It does a good job for those who do bad.

paragraphs.original: Now thou dost ill to say the gallows is built stronger than the church. Argal, the gallows may do well to thee. To 't again, come.
paragraphs.translated:
Now, it's wrong to say that the gallows are stronger than a church. Therefore, the gallows may do you some good. Come on, your turn.
you

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
"Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or a carpenter?"
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Let's see, "Who builds stronger things than a stonemason, a shipbuilder, or a carpenter?"

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Ay, tell me that, and unyoke.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
That's the question, so answer it.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Marry, now I can tell.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Ah, I've got it!

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
To 't.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Go ahead.

paragraphs.original:
OTHER
Mass, I cannot tell.
paragraphs.translated:
OTHER
Damn, I forgot.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET and HORATIO afar off
HAMLET
HORATIO
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET and HORATIO enter in the distance.
HAMLET
HORATIO

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dull ass will not mend his pace with beating. And when you are asked this question next, say "A grave-maker." The houses that he makes last till doomsday. Go, get thee in. Fetch me a stoup of liquor.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Don't beat your brains out over it. You can't make a slow donkey run by beating it. The next time someone asks you this riddle, say "a gravedigger." The houses he makes last till Judgment Day. Now go and get me some booze.

paragraphs.original:
Exit OTHER
OTHER
paragraphs.translated:
The OTHER GRAVEDIGGER exits.
OTHER GRAVEDIGGER

paragraphs.original:
(digs and sings)
(digs and sings)
In youth when I did love, did love,
In youth when I did love, did love
Methought it was very sweet
Methought it was very sweet
To contract–o–the time, for–a–my behove,
To contract–o–the time, for–a–my behove
Oh, methought, there–a–was nothing–a–meet.
Oh, methought, there–a–was nothing–a–meet
paragraphs.translated:
(the GRAVEDIGGER digs and sings)
(the
digs and sings)
In my youth I loved, I loved,
In my youth I loved, I loved
And I thought it was very sweet
And I thought it was very sweet
To set - ohh - the date for - ahh - my duty
To set - ohh - the date for - ahh - my duty
Oh, I thought it - ahh - was not right.
Oh, I thought it - ahh - was not right

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Has this fellow no feeling of his business? He sings at grave- making.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Doesn't this guy realize what he's doing? He's singing while digging a grave.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
He's gotten so used to graves that they don't bother him anymore.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
'Tis e'en so. The hand of little employment hath the daintier sense.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Yes, exactly. Only people who don't have to work can afford to be sensitive.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
(sings)
(sings)
But age with his stealing steps
But age with his stealing steps
Hath clawed me in his clutch,
Hath clawed me in his clutch
And hath shipped me into the land
And hath shipped me into the land
As if I had never been such.
As if I had never been such
(throws up a skull)
(throws up a skull)
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
(sings)
(sings)
But old age has sneaked up on me
But old age has sneaked up on me
And grabbed me in his claws,
And grabbed me in his claws
And has shipped me into the ground
And has shipped me into the ground
As if I'd never been like that.
As if I'd never been like that
(he throws up a skull)
(he throws up a skull)

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
That skull had a tongue in it and could sing once. How the knave jowls it to the ground, as if it were Cain's jawbone, that did the first murder! It might be the pate of a politician, which this ass now o'erreaches, one that would circumvent God, might it not?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That skull had a tongue in it once and could sing. That jackass is throwing it around as if it belonged to Cain, who did the first murder! It might be the skull of a politician once capable of talking his way around God, right? And now this idiot is pulling rank on him.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
It might, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Or of a courtier, which could say, "Good morrow, sweet lord!" "How dost thou, good lord?" This might be my Lord Such-a-one that praised my Lord Such-a-one's horse when he meant to beg it, might it not?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Or a courtier, who could say things like, "Good night, my sweet lord! How are you doing, good lord?" This might be the skull of Lord So-and-So, who praised Lord Such-and-Such's horse when he wanted to borrow it, right?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, e'en so. And now my Lady Worm's, chapless and knocked about the mazard with a sexton's spade. Here's fine revolution, an we had the trick to see 't. Did these bones cost no more the breeding but to play at loggets with them? Mine ache to think on 't.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Exactly. And now it's the property of Lady Worm, its lower jaw knocked off and thwacked on the noggin with a shovel. That's quite a reversal of fortune, isn't it, if we could only see it? Are these bones worth nothing more than bowling pins now? It makes my bones ache to think about it.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
(sings)
(sings)
A pickax and a spade, a spade,
A pickax and a spade, a spade
For and a shrouding sheet,
For and a shrouding sheet
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.
For such a guest is meet
(throws up another skull)
(throws up another skull)
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
(sings)
(sings)
A pickax and a shovel, a shovel,
A pickax and a shovel, a shovel
And a sheet for a funeral shroud,
And a sheet for a funeral shroud
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
For a guest like this one here.
For a guest like this one here
(he throws up another skull)
(he throws up another skull)

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
There's another. Why may not that be the skull of a lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his quillities, his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? Why does he suffer this rude knave now to knock him about the sconce with a dirty shovel and will not tell him of his action of battery? Hum! This fellow might be in 's time a great buyer of land, with his statutes, his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries. Is this the fine of his fines and the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine pate full of fine dirt? Will his vouchers vouch him no more of his purchases, and double ones too, than the length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The very conveyances of his lands will hardly lie in this box, and must the inheritor himself have no more, ha?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
There's another. Could that be a lawyer's skull? Where's all his razzle-dazzle legal jargon now? Why does he allow this idiot to knock him on the head with a dirty shovel, instead of suing him for assault and battery? Maybe this guy was once a great landowner, with his deeds and contracts, his tax shelters and his annuities. Is it part of his deed of ownership to have his skull filled up with dirt? Does he only get to keep as much land as a set of contracts would cover if you spread them out on the ground? The deeds to his properties would barely fit in this coffin - and the coffin's all the property he gets to keep?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Not a jot more, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
No more than that, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Is not parchment made of sheepskins?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Isn't the parchment of a legal document made of sheepskin?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Ay, my lord, and of calfskins too.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Yes, my lord, and calfskin too.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance in that.
I will speak to this fellow. - Whose grave's this, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Anyone who puts his trust in such documents is a sheep or a calf. I'll talk to this guy. - Excuse me, sir, whose grave is this?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Mine, sir.
(sings)
(sings)
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
It's mine, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.
For such a guest is meet
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
For a guest like this one here.
For a guest like this one here

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I think it be thine, indeed, for thou liest in 't.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I think it really must be yours, since you're the one lying in it.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
You lie out on 't, sir, and therefore it is not yours. For my part, I do not lie in 't, and yet it is mine.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
And you're lying outside of it, so it's not yours. As for me, I'm not lying to you in it - it's really mine.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Thou dost lie in 't, to be in 't and say it is thine. 'Tis for the dead, not for the quick. Therefore thou liest.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
But you are lying in it, being in it and saying it's yours. It's for the dead, not the living. So you're lying.
are

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
'Tis a quick lie, sir. 'Twill away gain from me to you.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
That's a lively lie, sir - it jumps so fast from me to you.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
What man dost thou dig it for?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What man are you digging it for?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
For no man, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
For no man, sir.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
What woman, then?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What woman, then?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
For none, neither.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
For no woman, either.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Who is to be buried in 't?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Who's to be buried in it?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
One that was a woman, sir, but, rest her soul, she's dead.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
One who used to be a woman but - bless her soul - is dead now.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How absolute the knave is! We must speak by the card, or equivocation will undo us. By the Lord, Horatio, these three years I have taken a note of it. The age is grown so picked that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galls his kibe. - How long hast thou been a grave-maker?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How literal this guy is! We have to speak precisely, or he'll get the better of us with his wordplay. Lord, Horatio, I've been noticing this for a few years now. The peasants have become so clever and witty that they're nipping at the heels of noblemen. - How long have you been a gravedigger?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Of all the days i' the year, I came to 't that day that our last
King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Of all the days in the year, I started the day that the late King Hamlet defeated Fortinbras.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How long is that since?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How long ago was that?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Cannot you tell that? Every fool can tell that. It was the very day that young Hamlet was born, he that is mad and sent into England.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
You don't know that? Any fool could tell you, it was the day that young Hamlet was born - the one who went crazy and got sent off to England.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Why was he sent to England?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Why, because he was mad. He shall recover his wits there, or, if he do not, it's no great matter there.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Because he was crazy. He'll recover his sanity there. Or if he doesn't, it won't matter in England.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Why not?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
'Twill not be seen in him there. There the men are as mad as he.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Because nobody will notice he's crazy. Everyone there is as crazy as he is.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How came he mad?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How did he go crazy?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Very strangely, they say.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
In a strange way, they say.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How "strangely"?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
What do you mean, "in a strange way"?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
By losing his mind.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Upon what ground?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
On what grounds?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Why, here in Denmark. I have been sexton here, man and boy, thirty years.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Right here in Denmark. I've been the church warden here for thirty years, since childhood.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
How long will a man lie i' the earth ere he rot?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How long will a man lie in his grave before he starts to rot?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Faith, if he be not rotten before he die - as we have many pocky corses nowadays that will scarce hold the laying in -  he will last you some eight year or nine year. A tanner will last you nine year.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Well, if he's not rotten before he dies (and there are a lot of people now who are so rotten they start falling to pieces even before you put them in the coffin), he'll last eight or nine years. A leathermaker will last nine years.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why he more than another?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Why does he last longer?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
Why, sir, his hide is so tanned with his trade that he will keep out water a great while, and your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body. (indicates a skull) Here's a skull now. This skull has lain in the earth three-and-twenty years.
(indicates a skull)
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Because his hide is so leathery from his trade that he keeps the water off him a long time, and water is what makes your goddamn body rot more than anything. Here's a skull that's been here twenty-three years.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Whose was it?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Whose was it?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
A whoreson mad fellow's it was. Whose do you think it was?
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
A crazy bastard. Who do you think?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Nay, I know not.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I really don't know.

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! He poured a flagon of Rhenish on my head once. This same skull, sir, was Yorick's skull, the king's jester.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Damn that crazy madman! He poured a pitcher of white wine on my head once. This is the skull of Yorick, the king's jester.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
This?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
This one?

paragraphs.original:
GRAVEDIGGER
E'en that.
paragraphs.translated:
GRAVEDIGGER
Yes, that one.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Let me see. (takes the skull) Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio, a fellow of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy. He hath borne me on his back a thousand times, and now, how abhorred in my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it. Here hung those lips that I have kissed I know not how oft.  - Where be your gibes now? Your gambols? Your songs? Your flashes of merriment that were wont to set the table on a roar? Not one now to mock your own grinning? Quite chapfallen? Now get you to my lady's chamber and tell her, let her paint an inch thick, to this favor she must come. Make her laugh at that. - Prithee, Horatio, tell me one thing.
(takes the skull)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Let me see. (he takes the skull) Oh, poor Yorick! I used to know him, Horatio - a very funny guy, and with an excellent imagination. He carried me on his back a thousand times, and now - how terrible - this is him. It makes my stomach turn. I don't know how many times I kissed the lips that used to be right here. Where are your jokes now? Your pranks? Your songs?
(he takes the skull)
Your flashes of wit that used to set the whole table laughing? You don't make anybody smile now. Are you sad about that? You need to go to my lady's room and tell her that no matter how much makeup she slathers on, she'll end up just like you some day. That'll make her laugh. Horatio, tell me something.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
What's that, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
What's that, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Dost thou think Alexander looked o' this fashion i' th' earth?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Do you think Alexander the Great looked like this when he was buried?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
E'en so.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Exactly like that.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
And smelt so? Pah! (puts down the skull)
(puts down the skull)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
And smelled like that, too? Whew! (he puts down the skull)
(he puts down the skull)

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
E'en so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Just as bad, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
To what base uses we may return, Horatio. Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bunghole?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
How low we can fall, Horatio. Isn't it possible to imagine that the noble ashes of Alexander the Great could end up plugging a hole in a barrel?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
'Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
If you thought that you'd be thinking too much.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
No, faith, not a jot. But to follow him thither with modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it, as thus: Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander returneth to dust, the dust is earth, of earth we make loam - and why of that loam, whereto he was converted, might they not stop a beer barrel?
Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay,
Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,
Should patch a wall t' expel the winter's flaw!
But soft, but soft a while.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
No, not at all. Just follow the logic: Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander returned to dust, the dust is dirt, and dirt makes mud we use to stop up holes. So why can't someone plug a beer barrel with the dirt that used to be Alexander? The great emperor Caesar, dead and turned to clay, might plug up a hole to keep the wind away. Oh, to think that the same body that once ruled the world could now patch up a wall! But quiet, be quiet a minute.

paragraphs.original:
Enter King CLAUDIUS, Queen GERTRUDE, LAERTES, and a coffin, with a PRIEST and other lords attendant.
CLAUDIUS
GERTRUDE
LAERTES
PRIEST
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS enters with GERTRUDE, LAERTES, and a coffin, with a PRIEST and other lords attendant.
CLAUDIUS
GERTRUDE
LAERTES
PRIEST

paragraphs.original:
Here comes the king,
The queen, the courtiers - who is this they follow,
And with such maimèd rites? This doth betoken
The corse they follow did with desperate hand
Fordo its own life. 'Twas of some estate.
Couch we a while and mark.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the king, the queen, and the noblemen of court. Who are they following? And with such a plain and scrawny ceremony? It means the corpse they're following took its own life. Must have been from a wealthy family. Let's stay and watch a while.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET and HORATIO withdraw
HAMLET
HORATIO
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET and HORATIO step aside.
HAMLET
HORATIO

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
What ceremony else?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
What other rites are you going to give her?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
That is Laertes, a very noble youth, mark.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That's Laertes, a very noble young man. Listen.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
What ceremony else?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
What other rites are you going to give her?

paragraphs.original:
PRIEST
Her obsequies have been as far enlarged
As we have warranty. Her death was doubtful,
And, but that great command o'ersways the order,
She should in ground unsanctified have lodged
Till the last trumpet. For charitable prayers
Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her.
Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants,
Her maiden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.
paragraphs.translated:
PRIEST
I've performed as many rites as I'm permitted. Her death was suspicious, and were it not for the fact that the king gave orders to bury her here, she'd have been buried outside the church graveyard. She deserves to have rocks and stones thrown on her body. But she has had prayers read for her and is dressed up like a pure virgin, with flowers tossed on her grave and the bell tolling for her.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Must there no more be done?
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Isn't there any other rite you can perform?

paragraphs.original:
PRIEST
No more be done.
We should profane the service of the dead
To sing a requiem and such rest to her
As to peace-parted souls.
paragraphs.translated:
PRIEST
No, nothing. We would profane the other dead souls here if we sang the same requiem for her that we sang for them.

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Lay her i' th' earth,
And from her fair and unpolluted flesh
May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,
A ministering angel shall my sister be
When thou liest howling.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Lay her in the ground, and let violets bloom from her lovely and pure flesh!
I'm telling you, you jerk priest, my sister will be an angel in heaven while you're howling in hell.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
(to HORATIO) What, the fair Ophelia?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(to HORATIO) What, the beautiful Ophelia?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Sweets to the sweet. Farewell! (scatters flowers)
(scatters flowers)
I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet's wife.
I thought thy bride-bed to have decked, sweet maid,
And not have strewed thy grave.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN
Sweet flowers for a sweet girl. Goodbye! (she scatters flowers) I once hoped you'd be my Hamlet's wife. I thought I'd be tossing flowers on your wedding bed, my sweet girl, not on your grave.
(she scatters flowers)

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
Oh, treble woe
Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head,
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
Deprived thee of! Hold off the earth awhile
Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
Oh, damn three times, damn ten times the evil man whose wicked deed deprived you of your ingenious mind. Hold off burying her until I've caught her in my arms once more.

paragraphs.original: (leaps into the grave)
paragraphs.translated: (he jumps into the grave)

paragraphs.original:
Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made,
T' o'ertop old Pelion or the skyish head
Of blue Olympus.
paragraphs.translated:
Now pile the dirt onto the living and the dead alike, till you've made a mountain higher than
Mount Pelion or Mount Olympus.
Mount Pelion or Mount Olympus

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
(comes forward) What is he whose grief
(comes forward)
Bears such an emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,
Hamlet the Dane. (leaps into the grave)
(leaps into the grave)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(coming forward) Who is the one whose grief is so loud and clear, whose words of sadness make the planets stand still in the heavens as if they've been hurt by what they've heard? It's me, Hamlet the Dane. (he jumps into the grave)
(coming forward)
(he jumps into the grave)

paragraphs.original:
LAERTES
The devil take thy soul!
paragraphs.translated:
LAERTES
To hell with your soul!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET and LAERTES grapple
HAMLET
LAERTES
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET and LAERTES wrestle with each other.
HAMLET
LAERTES

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Thou pray'st not well.
I prithee, take thy fingers from my throat,
For though I am not splenitive and rash,
Yet have I something in me dangerous,
Which let thy wisdom fear. Hold off thy hand.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That's no way to pray. (they fight) Please take your hands off my throat. I may not be rash and quick to anger, but I have something dangerous in me which you should beware of. Take your hands off.
(they fight)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
Pluck them asunder.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Pull them apart.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
Hamlet, Hamlet!
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Hamlet! Hamlet!

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Gentlemen -
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Gentlemen!

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
(to HAMLET) Good my lord, be quiet.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
(to HAMLET ) Please, my lord, calm down.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
Attendants separate HAMLET and LAERTES
HAMLET
LAERTES
paragraphs.translated:
Attendants separate HAMLET and LAERTES
HAMLET
LAERTES

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, I will fight with him upon this theme
Until my eyelids will no longer wag.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'll fight him over this issue till I don't have the strength to blink.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
O my son, what theme?
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
Oh, my son, what issue is that?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I loved Ophelia. Forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of love
Make up my sum. What wilt thou do for her?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I loved Ophelia. Forty thousand brothers, if you added all their love together, couldn't match mine. What are you going to do for her?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
O, he is mad, Laertes.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Oh, he's crazy, Laertes!

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
For love of God, forbear him.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
For the love of God, be patient with him.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
'Swounds, show me what thou'lt do.
Woo't weep? Woo't fight? Woo't fast? Woo't tear thyself?
Woo't drink up eisel, eat a crocodile?
I'll do 't. Dost thou come here to whine,
To outface me with leaping in her grave?
Be buried quick with her? - and so will I.
And if thou prate of mountains let them throw
Millions of acres on us, till our ground,
Singeing his pate against the burning zone,
Make Ossa like a wart! Nay, an thou'lt mouth,
I'll rant as well as thou.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Damn it, show me what you're going to do for her. Will you cry? Fight? Stop eating? Cut yourself? Drink vinegar? Eat a crocodile? I'll do all that. Did you come here to whine? To outdo me by jumping into her grave so theatrically? To be buried alive with her? So will I. And if you rattle on about mountains, then let them throw millions of acres over us. It will be so high a peak that it scrapes against heaven and makes Mount Ossa look like a wart. See? I can talk crazy as well as you.

paragraphs.original:
GERTRUDE
This is mere madness.
And thus a while the fit will work on him.
Anon, as patient as the female dove
When that her golden couplets are disclosed,
His silence will sit drooping.
paragraphs.translated:
GERTRUDE
This is pure insanity. He'll be like this for a little while. Then he'll be as calm and quiet as a dove waiting for her eggs to hatch.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Hear you, sir.
What is the reason that you use me thus?
I loved you ever. But it is no matter.
Let Hercules himself do what he may,
The cat will mew and dog will have his day.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Listen, sir, why do you treat me like this? I always loved you. But it doesn't matter. Even a hero like Hercules can't keep cats from acting like cats, and dogs like dogs.

paragraphs.original:
Exit HAMLET
HAMLET
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET exits.
HAMLET

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIUS
I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIUS
Please, Horatio, go with him.

paragraphs.original:
Exit HORATIO
HORATIO
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO exits.
HORATIO

paragraphs.original:
(to LAERTES) Strengthen your patience in our last night's speech.
(to
)
We'll put the matter to the present push. - 
Good Gertrude, set some watch over your son. - 
This grave shall have a living monument.
An hour of quiet shortly shall we see.
Till then in patience our proceeding be.
Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HAMLET and HORATIO
HAMLET
HORATIO
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET and HORATIO enter.
HAMLET
HORATIO

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
So much for this, sir. Now shall you see the other.
You do remember all the circumstance?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
That's enough about that. Now I'll tell you the other story about my journey. Do you remember the circumstances?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Remember it, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
How could I forget, my lord!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleep. Methought I lay
Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Rashly - 
And praised be rashness for it: let us know
Our indiscretion sometimes serves us well
When our deep plots do pall, and that should teach us
There's a divinity that shapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will -
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
There was a kind of war in my brain that wouldn't let me sleep. It was worse than being a captive in chains. Sometimes it's good to be rash - sometimes it works out well to act impulsively when our careful plans lose steam. This should show us that there's a God in heaven who's always guiding us in the right direction, however often we screw up -

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
That is most certain.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Well, of course.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Up from my cabin,
My sea-gown scarfed about me, in the dark
Groped I to find out them, had my desire,
Fingered their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine own room again, making so bold
(My fears forgetting manners) to unseal
Their grand commission, where I found, Horatio - 
O royal knavery! - an exact command,
Larded with many several sorts of reasons
Importing Denmark's health, and England's too,
With - ho! - such bugs and goblins in my life
That, on the supervise (no leisure bated,
No, not to stay the grinding of the ax)
My head should be struck off.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
So I came up from my cabin with my robe tied around me, groped in the dark to find what I was looking for, found it, looked through their packet of papers, and returned to my cabin again. I was bold enough (I guess my fears made me forget my manners) to open the document containing the king's instructions. And there I found, Horatio, such royal mischief - a precisely worded order, sugared with lots of talk about Denmark's well-being and England's too, to cut off my head, without even waiting to sharpen the ax.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Is it possible?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
(shows HORATIO a document)
(shows
a document)
Here's the commission. Read it at more leisure.
But wilt thou hear me how I did proceed?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(he shows HORATIO a document) Here's the document. Read it in your free time. But do you want to hear what I did then?
(he shows
a document)

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Yes, please tell me.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Being thus benetted round with villainies - 
Ere I could make a prologue to my brains,
They had begun the play - I sat me down,
Devised a new commission, wrote it fair.
I once did hold it, as our statists do,
A baseness to write fair, and labored much
How to forget that learning, but, sir, now
It did me yeoman's service. Wilt thou know
Th' effect of what I wrote?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
So there I was, caught in their evil net. Before I could even start processing the situation, they had started the ball rolling. I sat down and wrote out a new official document with new instructions. I wrote it in a bureaucrat's neat handwriting. I used to think having nice handwriting was for servants, just like our politicians think, and I had to work hard to overcome that prejudice - but it sure came in handy then. Do you want to know what I wrote?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Ay, good my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
An earnest conjuration from the king,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like the palm might flourish,
As peace should stiff her wheaten garland wear
And stand a comma 'tween their amities,
And many suchlike "as's" of great charge,
That, on the view and knowing of these contents,
Without debatement further, more or less,
He should the bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
A sincere plea from the king, who commands the respect of England, and who hopes that the love between the two countries can flourish, and that peace can join them in friendship - and other fancy mumbo jumbo like that - saying that, once they read this document, without any debate, the ones delivering the letter should be put to death immediately, without giving them time to confess to a priest.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
How was this sealed?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
But how could you put an official seal on it?

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, even in that was heaven ordinant.
I had my father's signet in my purse,
Which was the model of that Danish seal.
Folded the writ up in form of th' other,
Subscribed it, gave 't th' impression, placed it safely,
The changeling never known. Now, the next day
Was our sea fight, and what to this was sequent
Thou know'st already.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Heaven helped me out with that too. I had my father's signet ring in my pocket, with the royal seal of Denmark on it. I folded up the new document, signed it, sealed it, and put it safely back so that no one noticed any difference. The next day we had our fight at sea, and you know what happened after that.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to 't.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
So Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are in for it.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Why, man, they did make love to this employment.
They are not near my conscience. Their defeat
Does by their own insinuation grow.
'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensèd points
Of mighty opposites.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Man, they were asking for it. I don't feel guilty about them at all. They got what they deserved. It's always dangerous when little people get caught in the crossfire of mighty opponents.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Why, what a king is this!
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
What a king Claudius is!

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
Does it not, think thee, stand me now upon - 
He that hath killed my king and whored my mother,
Popped in between th' election and my hopes,
Thrown out his angle for my proper life
(And with such cozenage!) - is 't not perfect conscience
To quit him with this arm? And is 't not to be damned
To let this canker of our nature come
In further evil?
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Don't you think it's my duty now to kill him with this weapon? This man who killed my king, made my mother a whore, took the throne that I hoped for, and set a trap to kill me. Isn't it completely moral to kill him now with this sword - and an easy conscience? And wouldn't I be damned if I let this monster live to do more harm?

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
He'll find out soon what happened in England.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
It will be short. The interim's mine.
And a man's life's no more than to say "one."
But I am very sorry, good Horatio,
That to Laertes I forgot myself,
For by the image of my cause I see
The portraiture of his. I'll court his favors.
But sure the bravery of his grief did put me
Into a towering passion.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Soon enough. But I have the meantime. A human life is hardly long enough to count to one in. But I really feel bad, Horatio, about losing control of myself with Laertes. His situation is very much like my own. I'll be nice to him. It was just that the showiness of his grief sent me into a fury.

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
Peace. - Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
Hang on a minute - who are you?

paragraphs.original:
Enter young OSRIC, a courtier, hat in hand
OSRIC
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC, a young courtier, enters with his hat in his hand.
OSRIC

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
Welcome back to Denmark, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I humbly thank you, sir. (aside to HORATIO) Dost know this water-fly?
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Thank you kindly, sir. (speaking so that only HORATIO can hear) Do you know this insect?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
HORATIO
(aside to HAMLET) No, my good lord.
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
HORATIO
(speaking so that only HAMLET can hear) No, my lord.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
(aside to HORATIO) Thy state is the more gracious, for 'tis a vice to know him. He hath much land, and fertile. Let a beast be lord of beasts and his crib shall stand at the king's mess. 'Tis a chough, but, as I say, spacious in the possession of dirt.
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
(speaking so that only HORATIO can hear) You're lucky, since knowing him is most unpleasant. He owns a lot of good land. Give an animal a lot of money, and he'll be welcome at the king's table. He's a jerk, but he owns a whole lot of dirt, so he's treated well.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from His Majesty.
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
My lord, if you have a free moment, I have a message from His Majesty.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I will receive it, sir, with all diligence of spirit. Put your bonnet to his right use. 'Tis for the head.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
I'll hang on every word you say. Put your hat back on, where it belongs: it's for your head, not for your hands to hold.

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
I thank your lordship. It is very hot.
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
No thank you, my lord. It's very hot.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
No, believe me, 'tis very cold. The wind is northerly.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
No, I'm telling you, it's very cold, with a northerly wind.

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
It is rather cold, indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my complexion.
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
And yet I feel it's very hot and humid, which is bad for my complexion.

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
Exceedingly, my lord. It is very sultry - as 'twere - I cannot tell how. My lord, his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head. Sir, this is the matter -
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
Yes indeed it is, sir. Very humid, I can't tell you how humid it is. My lord, His Majesty wanted me to tell you that he's placed a large bet on you. This is what it's all about -

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
I beseech you, remember - (indicates that OSRIC should put on his hat)
(indicates that
should put on his hat)
paragraphs.translated:
HAMLET
Please, I beg you - (he points to OSRIC 's hat)
(he points to
's hat)

paragraphs.original:
OSRIC
Nay, good my lord, for mine ease, in good faith. Sir, here is newly come to court Laertes, believe me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent differences, of very soft society and great showing. Indeed, to speak feelingly of him, he is the card or calendar of gentry, for you shall find in him the continent of what part a gentleman would see.
paragraphs.translated:
OSRIC
No, my lord, I'm comfortable like this, thank you. Sir, there's someone named Laertes who's recently come to the court. He's an absolute gentleman, totally outstanding in so many respects, very easy in society, and displaying all his excellent qualities.
If I were to expose my true feelings about him, I'd have to say he's like a business card for the upper classes - he's that wonderful. You'll find that he's the sum total of what a perfect gentleman should be.
If I were to expose my true feelings about him

paragraphs.original:
HAMLET
